He takes back his battle helmet, fits it on his hea The Soldier STARES at the pot of WATER -~ watching FIRST confusion and then with dawning realization as its surfac starts to SWAY like a tide-pool --

dialogues.text: (suddenly POINTING his

ANOTHER CRACK and the MINE WALL starte to CRUMBLE, HANDS PICK-AXRES now pushing through... The MINE WALL COLLAPSES INWARDS, CYPRIOT KNIGHTS now push their way through into the shadows --

dialogues.speaker: NOW
dialogues.text: -- but before the Cypriot Knights can react the English Tunnel Soldiers are on them, ATTACKING from the darkness close quarters, SLICING with their swords, HACKING with t picks, taking out their surprised enemies one-by-onel Steel flashes by torchlight and the Cypriot Knights try t fight back, but they’re totally unprepared for the Englis onslaught. The surviving Cypriots RETREAT back into their OWN TUNNEL, Tornham and his fellow English Tunnel Soldier

dialogues.text: Up on the parapets of the Castle Walls the remaining Engl defenders watch and CHEER as their comrades proceed to wi the battle... cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: EST. MANORHOUSE
dialogues.text: Close to the edge of a FOREST sits a cross between a mans and a castle, wealthy lodgings surrounded by a defensible wall. But there's no sign of a siege here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GREAT WALL is filled with Foop and DRINK, along with MUSIC and LAUGHTER. It’s a FEAST for well-to-do NOBLE and KNIGHTLY FAMILIES, attended to by an array of MALE and FE SERVANTS. A ROUNDEL DANCE is in progress, MEN AND WOMEN a 14 and up twirling in each others arme to the flutes and drums of the MUSICIANS and the lilt of the accompanying CHORAL’ S VOICES. o + A good time is being had by all -- but one good-looking Y MAN and equally well-—bred YOUNG WOMAN, both Nobles, are dancing together and virtually glowing with joy.  Se They exchange a series of looks, ending with each of them NODDING to the other, then take advantage of the crowd to surreptitiously DUCK OUTSIDE -~ the Young Woman reaching to SNATCH A GOBLET OF BRANDYWINE off a serving tray as sh @xLTB oes

dialogues.speaker: BXT. MANORHOUSE
dialogues.text: The Young Woman sips from the goblet and makes an impromp SPRINT for the forest, the Young Man giving chase ~~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Young Man watches as. the Young Woman leans back agai LARGE TREE, raises the goblet to her lips and sucks it dr

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: (feigning sadness) We're out of brandywine. The Young Man pins her against the tree, pulls off her he dress, letting her hair tumble down onto both their faces

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: (hushed) oe GOO. -- and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: DEEPER IN THE FOREST
dialogues.text: A STAG with a large pair of antlers silently watches as t young noble couple begins to make love...

dialogues.speaker: THE YOUNG COUPLE
dialogues.text: Wrapped in each others arms, kissing passionately -- unti the SOUND of a BREAKING BRANCH startles them. They freeze the Young Man peering into the shadewy woods around them The Stag emerges from the darkness. The Young Woman smiles at the noble creature.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: He's beautiful. The Young Man kisses the Young Woman on the neck --

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: So are you. She MOANS as he moves his lips towards her breasts -- A sudden HIGH-PITCHED WHISTLING SOUND fills the night ai Then a sharp, jagged THUD. The eyes of both the Young Man and the Young Woman go WID their breath catching in their throats. A single ARROW has gone through the Young Man’s BACK and the Young Woman’s CHEST, IMPALING them both INTO THE TREE The startled Buck races back into the woods -- leaving th young couple frozen together in shock, bleeding to death. cur TOs EXT. CASTLE MARCAPPUS — DAWN The Last time we saw this place it was under attack -- bu now it sits calm and peaceful beneath the warm light of a early Mediterranean morning... INT. CASTLE BED-CHAMBER -— BARLY MORNING Robert Tornham wakes, throws off his blanket and sits up bed —- revealing himself to be completely naked. Blinks h eyes, wipes sleep from them, takes a deep breath -- then pulls himself out of bed, turns to the East, where the su has just risen, and kneels in PRAYER:

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: Our Father, who desires that we all be saved and gives us our daily bread ~- the Holy Sacrament for the goul and needful sustenance for the body, For these I confide in you. Amen. Tornham crises, reaches over to a simple NIGHT-STAND, pou pitcher of WATER into a bowl and SPLASHES some on his fac Then he wraps 4 piece of white linen around his index fin dips it fireat into the water, then in a small. TRON SAUC SALT -- and uses it to BRUSH HIS TEBTH. When he’s done he crosses to the WINDOW, undoes an TRON BAR and OPENS THE SHUTTERS, allowing the sunlight to stream in. He breathes in the morning, opens his mouth in a great ya then heads through a narrow ARCHWAY and down a narrow sto PASSAGE that winds ite way to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ie what we now call the toilet. ‘Tornham ~~ still na sits down to do his business... While he sits he studies a CHESSBOARD laid out beside hi seat, the pieces in the MIDST OF AN ONGOING GAME, He thin for a moment, makes a MOVE ~- then sping the board around he’s now playing black instead of white -- considers a moment, then makes another move... cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tornham, now fully dressed, enters ~~ and furrows his bro the surprising sight of his SQUIRE, THOMAS LESLIE -~ 60, but not wizened, still in impressive shape for his age -- is in the midst of PACKING up everything in the room in a secles of BAGS and BOXES ~~

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: Good morning, Sir Robert. I trust your breakfast met with approval? Can you believe the locals on this island prefer cow's milk on their cereal to wine?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Thankfully I have you to protect me from such dire threats. (ce: the packing) What in God's name are you up to?

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: Tt seems word of your brilliant counter-mining stratagem and its utter defeat of the rebellious locals reached the Royal ears of King Richard -- and His Majesty was quite impressed. In fact, he sent you 4 personal message to that effect ~~ (indicating an unrolled PARCHMENT sitting on the desk) ~~ which I took the liberty of opening, not wishing to disturb that blissfully deep slumber of YOUrS Tornham shoota the old man a Look.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: People warned me about employing a squire who could read. (nodding at the parchment on the desk) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TORNHAM (cont'd) So what does King Richard's congratulatory letter have to do with you packing up all my things?

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: i'm afraid it's a “good news, bad news” letter, sir. It seems you are no longer the Sheriff of Cyprus. Tornham Looks at his Squire in confusion -~ ‘TORNHAM What? That‘s not possible. Richard appointed me for life. (angrily) Give me that letter. The Squire pauses his packing, hands Yornham the parchmen

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: Yes, well, that was before he decided to sell the Island and all its contents and inhabitants to the Knights Templar. Now Tornham’s confusion turns to total disbelief --

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: He sold the island? But we just won a desperate victory over the entire Army of Cyprus defending this place for him.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: And don't think he doesn’t appreciate it. That's where the good news comes in... The Squire flips over the parchment and brings Tornham’s attention to the writing at the bottom of the SECOND PAGE which carries an EMBOSSED ROYAL SEAL...

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Xou, Six Robert Tornham, are no longer Sheriff of Cyprua but ~- thanks to your well-proven loyalty, courage and resourcefulness —- you have just been appointed to be the Sheriff... of Nottingham. Tornham looka like someone just threw cold water on his f Me quickly reads over both pages of parchment for himself  He doesn’t look happy or sad ~- just stunned.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: (re: packing it up) I assume I’1] find your chess set in the privy...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I£ you can call it day, between the grey CLOUDS and DRIZZ RAIN. A PAIR OF HORSEMEN gallop their way down the muddy remnant of a dirt ROAD... it’s Tornham and Squire Thomas, both of their horses loaded down with SADDLEBAGS of food, clothing and books...

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: (dry) . Merry old England. Just as lovely as I remembered it. Aren’t you giad to be home, sir?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Do you know where the word “Sarcasm” comes from, Thomas?

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: I believe from the French SAaLcasMme «a>

dialogues.speaker: TORMTAM
dialogues.text: »eewho got it from the Latin Sarcasmus -~ which got it from the Greek Sarkasmos ~- which got it from the ancient Greek Sarkazein. De you know what Serkazein means in ancient Greek, Thomas?

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: An ignorant squire such as myself? of course not, six. Please do enlighten me. An awkward beat -~

dialogues.speaker: ORNHAM
dialogues.text: Damm. IL can’t remember. But we're nowhere near Greece anymore, ao if you could lessen the amount of ~~ SQUIRE ‘THOMAS Sarkazein?  10.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: It would be greatly appreciated. The two travellers reach the top of a RISE IN THE ROAD an URBAN LANDSCAPE becomes visible in the distance laid out below them...

dialogues.speaker: NOTTINGHAM, ENGLAND
dialogues.text: EXT. SUBURBS OF NOTTINGHAM — DAY The road becomes lined with scattered HOUSES, which quick in turn give way to BIGGER, MORE EXPENSIVE and CLOSER-PAC HOUSES and TAVERNS. The road here bears some TRAFFIC, mos of it headed in the same direction as Tornham and Squire Thomas: NORTH, towards a tall STONE WALL which looms in t distance... Outside one of the Taverns, an INN-~KEEPER spots Tornham Squire Thomas as they approach, emiles and CALLS OUT:

dialogues.speaker: INN-KEEPER
dialogues.text: Good-day to you, good-sirg! Within this establishment of mine you shall find all manner of comforts, painted chambers and soft beds piled so high with feather mattresses you can nearly touch the ceiling with your finger. Here is your lodging for love affairs -- for you must trust me when I tell you how sweetly becoming are those lovely damsels who abide within! Sguixe Thomas inspects the Tavern ~- several YOUNG WOMEN their heads out of the windows, some attractive, some not but all locking weary.

dialogues.speaker: TORNEHAM
dialogues.text: I assume you are familiar with the “Diverse Ordinances and Constitutions for the Regulation of Horrible Sin® as enacted by our late, great King Henry IT, may God bless his memory as he rests in peace?

dialogues.speaker: INN-KEEPER
dialogues.text: (tentatively) Mumm... I've heard of them.  di.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Seo... if we were to enter your “establishment” we would find no woman residing there whom you charge more than fourteen pence a week for hex room?

dialogues.speaker: INN
dialogues.text: (nervously) Those ordinances were a long time ago! Prices rise, the value of money falls. You have to keep up with the market. TORNHAM . Nonetheless, I advise you to lower the rent you charge in accordance with the law of the land. I/‘11 send a Bailiff by to check -- and i£ you're not in accordance, to levy the appropriate fines. Tornham turns his horse round and makes for the gate. squ Thomas confides to the Inn-Keeper --

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: There's a new Sheriff in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tornham and Squire Thomas reach an OPEN pair of massive WOODEN DOORS set in the STONE WALL which stretches around entire perimeter of the CITY. A steady stream of TWO-WAY TRAFFIC is passing in and out under the watchful gaze of a pair of GUARDSMEN, One of th WAVES to Tornham and Squire Thomas:

dialogues.speaker: GUARDSMAN
dialogues.text: Please identify yourselves, gentlemen. Tornham starts to reply, but Squire Thomas jumps in first

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: Sir Robert Tornham »~ the newly appointed Sheriff of Nottingham. the Guards exchange a look and don't seem convinced. Torn reaches beneath his suxrcoat, pulls out the PARCHMENT and shows them the EMBOSSED ROYAL SEAL..  12.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: I doubt you boys can read but I have faith you can recognize the Great. Seal of King Richard -- can’t you? The Guardsmen’s eyes go wide and they quickly BOW their h to Tornham and gesture for him to pass ~- then one begins cringing an ALARM BELL perched atop the gates -~

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: I would advise us both to be prepared for either a shower of riches or a surprise attack, Tornham and Squire Thomas ride on into the HEART OF THE C It is a late 12th Century METROPOLIS and so far as Englis cities go, second only to London in its population, urbanization and sophistication. Before Tornham and Squire Thomas can get much further up MAIN ROAD they are suddenly SET UPON by a NOBLEMAN on horseback, accompanied by FOUR KWIGHTS, all five horsemen CHARGING their way through the CITY STREETS, pulling thei mounts to a stop just in front of Tornham and his squire The Nobleman -- intense eyes, chiseled face and chiseled body -- nods from atop his horse:

dialogues.speaker: NOBLEMAN
dialogues.text: Sir Robert Tornham, Sheriff of Nottingham, I presume? I’ve been expecting you. (pulling his horse up alongside Tornham, offering hig HAND) Guy of Gisborne. I've been serving as acting sheriff until a royal appointment was made for the office.

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: (SHAKING Gisborne’s hand) Pleasure to meet you, Sir Guy.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE, (NOBLEMAN)
dialogues.text: Pardon me for agking, Sir Robert, but... where is your escort? Your retainers? Squire Thomas clears his throat, raises a hand -~  13.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: That would be me. Gisborne skeptically eyes the old man.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Wo offense, Sir Robert -- but one rusty man-at~arms? It’s insanity. There are murdering thieves hiding behind every bush in England these days -- especially along the Great North Road which you took up from Londen. Squire Thomas starts to reply but Tornham cuts him off --

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: All no doubt looking to ambush and rob blind every Nobleman trotting through the woods with an impressive entourage and wagons filled with treasure and fineries. (a beat) i've got one wagon coming with all my belongings and the rest of my retainers. They should be here in the next few days. Gisborne acknowledges this with a reluctant nod and indic an impregnable-looking CASTLE atop the bill at the center the city --

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Your office awaits you in Nottingham Castle. Castle Hill is also the Norman section of the city. You'll want to stay close after hours. The Saxon section is on Saint Mary’s Will -~ though there’s not much “saintly* about At. Gisborne continues with the guided TOUR, he and his knigh leading Tornham and Squire Thomas on THROUGH THE cry ~~

dialogues.speaker: PEASANTS
dialogues.text: going through their daily routines...  14.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: (chiming in) I believe this town was founded by some of my Saxon ancestors after they invaded the island and wrested great swathes of it from the ancient Britons who inhabited it at the time. The Saxon chieftain in this region was a man named Snot and so this place was originally named Snottingham. (WHISPERING to Tornham) Sarkagein, Gisborne glares at the old Squire as Tornham suppresses a grin --

dialogues.speaker: TORNAHM
dialogues.text: (to Gisborne) What’s the population grown to these days, Sir Guy?

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Two-thousand give or take. Second only to London according to the latest census. A few less recently thanks to that bastard, Hood. Toernham narrows his eyes -~-

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: You haven’t heard of him? I’m surprised. The riff-raff have started to compose ballads celebrating his various crimes,

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: News from Nottingham doesn’t reach all the way to Cyprus.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Hoed -- Rebin of Locksley before he turned outlaw -- is a lesser nobleman of Saxon descent who hag been robbing, pillaging and now murdering those of Noble birth and Norman deacent for the last six months. The serfe and peasants proclaim him some sort of rebel champion. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GISBORNE (cont'd) A hero of the “common folk” because he throws them a few pennies now and again to keep their mouths shut as to his whereabouts. (shrugging) And so long as he only kills wealthy Normans the peasants and townsfolk could care less. They blame his murders on the Jews --~ though I've yet to meet a Jew who can shoot a strong bow well enough to kill two people with one arrow. Speaking of which... Gisborne nods to a RUN-DOWN SECTION OF THE CITY, a JEWISH STAR painted on an old wooded sign nailed to a post marki the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Saint Nicholas Lane -- the entrance to the Jewish quarter.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: God's chosen people.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE,
dialogues.text: More like God’s cursed. Last year they were burned out of York. Most of the survivors came to join their brethren here. They live piled atop one another like rats. Tornham SEES a boarded-up SYNAGOGUE in the distance and n to Gisborne ~~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Tf that’s the case, why is their synagogue boarded up?

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: It's only a few years old. Richard's new law declared that only those Jewish churches which stood during his father’s reign could remain open, go we shut thie one down. People say they gather to pray in their butcher shop now —- where it’s easy to slaughter Christian children and collect their blood. fornham exchanges a lock with his Squire...  16.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: No surprise there -- most of what people say is nonsense. cur To:

dialogues.speaker: EXT, NOTTINGHAM CASTLE
dialogues.text: THE DOORS are opened to admit Gisborne, Tornham and the others. They ride on, through the TUNNEL-LIKE interior of the castle GATEHOUSE and into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALETS take charge of the horses as Tornham, Gisborne and rest dismount -—-

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: I'd like to see the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: The two you said were killed with one arrow. Tell me, who raised the hue and cry when they were first discovered? An awkward moment of silence ~~ then Sir Guy confesses:

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: To be honest, Sheriff --- I don't really know. Does it matter? Tornham lets it slide and moves ons

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: The scene of the murder then. 711 have to gee that -- and anything else you have relating to the earlier murders as well.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: As you wiwh. Still, it seems a waste to me. Dead is dead and the killer is known to all.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Right. “Hood” -~ formerly Locksley. Well... I would appreciate it nonetheless.  a7. Gisborne stares at Tornham for a moment, then sighs =- an smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: I’m actually quite happy to be replaced, you know. I’m a soldier. War is my vocation. ALi this dealing with law, inquests, evidence... it’s quite senseless to me. Gisborne nods, BOWS to Tornham and marches off... cur TOs INT. CASTLE CHAMBER — DAY Tornham and Squire Thomas light CANDLES and place them throughout the large stone room... The DOOR suddenly swings OPEN and half-a-dozen LABORERS e carrying TWO LARGE SACKS -- Tornham and the old squire recoil from the SMELL -~

dialogues.speaker: LABORER
dialogues.text: Where‘d ya’ want ‘em, Sheriff? fornham POINTS to a LARGE WOODEN TABLE in the center of t chamber. The Laborers sling both linen bags up onto the tables, th BOW and leave. Tornham and Squire Thomas quickly tie SCARFS around their faces and approach the bags...

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: Only two bodies, six? Tornham nods as Thomas takes out a SHEAF OF PARCHMENTS an QUILL PEN and begins to WRIT# as Tornham speaks —~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Gieborne said there were three more before these ~~ each struck down with a aingle arrow ~- but those others have been buried in the earth too long to be of use to UB eee Tornhamn unwraps BOTH BAGS ~~ revealing the still relativ intact. BODIES of the YOUNG MAN and YOUNG WOMAN. ‘Tornham leans close, carefully INSPECTING both corpses -~  18. TORNHAM (CONT’D) They both have two wounds -~ entry and exit. Which would probably place them on top of one another at the time of death.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: I ¢an think of worse ways to end one's existence, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Don't let a priest hear you say that, Thomas, Our existence is not supposed to end with death. Tornham SEES something on the Young Man’s FACE -- a SUBST which he carefully scrapes off with his fingernail and se aside in a SMALL BOWL. He inspecte the body of the Young Woman, finds some on her lifeless face as well.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: What’s that, sir?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Beeswax, Tornham searches through the rest of the bags ~~ nothing, just the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Dammit. Not a stitch of clothing. Or the arrow.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: They must have declared the murder weapon a deodand ~~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: ~~ a “donation te God,” and seld it off to the highest bidder, yes. And the clothes were probably burned ~~

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: To keep theix immortal souls from getting stuck inside a tunic or gown en route to heaven. Happens all the time -- or so the priests would say.  19.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: {growing angry) These fools didn't bother to record who discovered the bodies, hold a proper inquest or preserve any evidence. How are we to solve these heinous crimes when all the evidence is gone?

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Six Guy didn’t seem to believe there was anything to solve, sir. Tornham throws the sackcloth back over the bodies in frustration ~~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Hood. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The edge of the woods surrounding the Manorhouse where th Young Couple were killed. Gisborne, Tornham and Squire Thomas ride up on horseback, Gisborne in the lead -~

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: This is the place. Tornham and Squire Thomas dismount, Gisborne watching fro atop bis horse.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s been weeks. I‘im sure the rains have washed away all traces ef blood and gore... if that is what you hope to find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tornham doesn’: reply. Instead he carefully inspects the area -- especially the TRUNK of a large TREN jutting from ground.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: He hides in these woods, you know.

dialogues.speaker: TORMHAM,
dialogues.text: {eyes still on the tree trunk) Who?  20.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Hood. He has some four-score men who follow him -- and they lurk behind these very trees, camouflaged in Lincoln Green. They wait for unsuspecting fools to provide them with sport, then disappear into the greenwood like the moon on a cloudy night.

dialogues.speaker: THE TREE TRUNK
dialogues.text: A DEEP GASH visible in the bark --

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: The young lovers. They were impaled on this tree, were they not? Here's the spot where the arrow hit, One arrow -- through the back -- blood, tissue, bone -~- and it keeps going, through more flesh and bone, out another back -~ imbedding in this tree. (chewing on his lip) It would take at least a 150 pound pull to penetrate all that. And definitely an armor-piercing bodkin -- no standard arrow could do this. And the shooter would have to be close.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: If you say so, Sheriff. My weapon of choice is the sword.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (explaining) An upright bow is accurate up to 400 yards but killing range is less than balf that. Richard’s foot~ soldiers prefer more modern crossbows but some still use this traditional weapon. I’ve seen it often in France, Italy and Cyprus -~- though I've never been particularly handy with a bow either. My weapon of choice is algo the blade. Tornham motions for his squire ~~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Thomas -- rope please.  al. Squire Thomas nods, quickly retrieves a BUNDLE of thin RO from a saddlebag and HOLDS ONE END UP TO THE ARROW-GASH i the tree-trunk. Tornham estimates the ANGLE OF FIRE, take the rope in his hands and WALKS OFF through the foliage, TRAILING THE ROPE TAUTLY BEHIND HIM as he JOCK. oe Tornham keeps walking until his way is BLOCKED BY ANOTHER TREE -— roughly 75 YARDS away from the murder site. Gisberne turns to Squire Thomas:

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: What in God‘s name is he doing?

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: Trying to discover exactly where the murderer stood when he fired the shot. Tornham turne and stares back through the foliage ~~ he h PERFECT SIGHT-LINE to the tree where the Young Couple wer killed. Tornham rejoins Gisborne and Squire Thomas ---

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (pointing to the Manorhouse) Who lives there?

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Lord Fitawater. It was his party the unfortunate young couple wandered off from that night.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: What was the occasion?

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: His daughter, Marian. She sits at home each night, wasting her beautiful young Life away waiting for her lover to return. I believe her father was trying to distract her. Remind ber there are other birds in the bush and bees in the hive. Encourage her to move on.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Who's the man who commands such undying loyalty?

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: (tight } Her lover was Robin of Locksley.  22. Tornham and Squire Thomas exchange a look -~ this is gett more interesting by the moment...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. ST. JOHN‘’S. HOSPITAL - DAY No doctors or surgical facilities -- in fact it’s closer modern HOMELESS SHELTER or HALFWAY HOUSE than a medical facility. The INMATES include a mix of the OLD, the DESTITUTE and the DISABLED -- ag well as able-bodied but impoverished WAYFARERS and those local SICK too ill to ca for themselves and too poor to afford a doctor. There is also one last category of inmate: the MENTALLY DERANGED - one of whom has been ferociously tearing at his side deep enough to draw blood with his long fingernails:

dialogues.speaker: ABOMINATION
dialogues.text: A YOUNG LADY VOLUNTEER is trying to settle him down. Her face has a fiery beauty but her eyes are much calmer, muc older, perhaps even a little wise —-~

dialogues.speaker: LADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: Master Haley, I am not here to tempt you but to tend to you. Before IT can do so you must return to your bed, take a breath and relax. He SCAMPERS away and THROWS THINGS to block her approach

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN HALEY
dialogues.text: CALL A MONK! I WANT A GOOD SON oF

dialogues.speaker: DAUGHTER OF EVE
dialogues.text: The Lady Volunteer makes a grab for the Madman but he SCAMPERS AWAY again, this time CLIMBING ATOP A BED bearin CRIPPLED YOUNG MAN using a fork to feed himsel£ Junch ~—

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN HALEY
dialogues.text: (tearing at bis side more forcefully) God ripped me and every man asunder in order to create you harlots! Understanding suddenly dawns on the Lady Volunteer’s face  23.

dialogues.speaker: LADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: Ripped asunder? You speak of Adam’s rib?

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN HALEY
dialogues.text: of course! On account of you we are incomplete, hollow and empty inside! The Lady stares up at the Madman for a moment, then calml smiles up at hime

dialogues.speaker: LADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: Shall I tell you what the reverend master Peter Lombard, a good son of Adam and a great man indeed, had te say on this very same subject?

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN HALEY
dialogues.text: “Lombard”? Was he Italian? I do like Italian wine.

dialogues.speaker: LADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: (moving CLOSER and CLOSER to him as she speaks) Well it was his view that God made a most perfect selection when he chose Adam’s rib for the creation of Eve. God did not make woman from Adam’s head, for she was not. intended to be his ruler, nor from his feet, for she was not intended to be his slave, but from his side -- for she was intended to be his companion and his friend. Not to make him hollow and empty as you claim, but complete and whole. The final masterpiece of creation. By now the Lady is standing smack in front of the Madman top of the bed ~- but his demeanor has changed and he rem quite calm. He ponders something for a moment, then shake hie head:

dialogues.speaker: MADMAN HALEY
dialogues.text: Those Italians may know wine but they don‘t know women. (going ice cold) i gay all you heartless witches deserve to die. Madman Haley suddenly SNATCHES THE FORK out of the Crippl Young Man’s hand and goes to STAB the Lady with it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she manages to GRAB A PILLOW OFF THE BED and uses it

dialogues.speaker: BLOCK THE THRUST
dialogues.text: The rest of the Inmates watch in shock and disbelief from their beds as the Lady and the Madman FIGHT TOOTH AND NAI for the fork -- A STRONG ARM SUDDENLY WRAPS ITSELF AROUND THE MADMAN’S NE AND YANKS HIM OFF THE LADY AND OFF THE BED -~— It's Tormham. He holds Madman Haley flailing wildly in hi arm for a moment, then POUNDS A FIST INTO THE BACK OF HIS HEAD, knocking him UNCONSCIOUS, and lets him drop to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: LADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: What. have you done?! Without skipping a beat, the Lady goes to Madman Haley's and examines him with gentle concern...

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: What have I done? Milady, are you ~~

dialogues.speaker: LADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: IT am not your lady and z do not appreciate your “heroic rescue.” Now come help me get this poor man back inte his bed! Tornham does as he’s told and together he and the Lady ca the Madman over to his empty bed and lay him down on it. _thady instantly starts tending to Madman Haley's self- inflicted WOUND, using clean water, balm and bandages...

dialogues.speaker: LADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: He has for some time been fallen out. of his right mind and I assure you that beating on him Like an animal will not restore his wits.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Tt was not his wits I was concerned with restoring but your safety, Ma‘am., Forgive me if I have offended you but I believe most men in my position would have been far less merciful and xun the maniac through with their sword.

dialogues.speaker: LADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: On the road or in the forest perhaps ~~ but not in a hospital. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LADY VOLUNTEER (cont'd) There are different. rules of behavior here. The Lady suddenly lifts her eyes from the Madman’s wounds really looks at Tornham for the first time...

dialogues.speaker: LADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: Do I knew you? Tornham looks back at her...

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: (turning her eyes back to the patient) Good. Tornham stands there rather uncomfortably, aware of being watched by all the other Inmates while the Lady volunteer keepe tending to the unconscious Madman. Tornham clears h throats

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Ma’am, you do not know me but I am in fact here to see you.

dialogues.speaker: LADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: Are you destitute?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: Crippled?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM,
dialogues.text: (anneyed) No.

dialogues.speaker: LADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: Lill -- but witheut means to afford @ iearned doctor's care?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (really annoyed) io.

dialogues.speaker: DADY VOLUNTEER
dialogues.text: Then T am afraid we have no facility to serve you.  26.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (losing his patience) I am not here for your service, woman -- but for mine. I am Sir Robert Tornham, newly-appointed Sheriff of this city of Nottingham ~~ and I must speak with you on sheriff's business. (a sudden afterthought) You are Maid Marian Fitzwater, are you not? MAID MARIAN ~~ the Lady -~ gives him a lool:

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN, (LADY VOLUNTEER)
dialogues.text: How did you guess?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I was told you are most uncommonly devoted to your work. {a beat) Now, if you've finished binding your maniac’s wound, I suggest we find someplace less crowded with the infirm and impoverished to talk. Marian studies Tornham, considers his words... curt TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tornham watches as Marian tends with a SPADE to a large GARDEN on the Hospital grounds. It’s filled with flower beds, fruit trees, vegetables and herbs --

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Your garden is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: And no doubt totally unappreciated by the lunatics inside. Maxian shoots him a look, pissed.  27.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: But it igs well appreciated by the great majority of patients who are not mad but simply poor and homeless -~- and even the mad appreciate the power of the medicinal herbs to lessen their affliction. {a beat) Please ask your questions and go. Tornham bites back some bile, proceeds:

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I’m told the Hospital staff here dips their own candles...

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: (nodding) I doit. It's much cheaper that way ~~ as long as you know what you're doing. Though I don’t see why it would be of concern to you.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: It's been my experience that during criminal inguiries, such small details invariably help reveal that which would otherwise remain hidden. (a beat) You are a... friend of the outlaw Robin Hood, known in his previous life as Six Robin of Locksley.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: Is that a question?

dialogues.speaker: TORNDAM
dialogues.text: No, Ma‘am, it's a etatement of fact -- ig it not?

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: Not quite. I'm actually hig fiancee. Tornham tries to bide his surprise -~ but fails.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: We were just about to marry when he was unjuetly outlawed. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIAN (CONT’D) We decided to postpone the marriage until his good name is exonerated and his lands and titles restored by good King Richard. (a beat) It was Robin's idea. He wanted to wait until he could provide a normal life for us —- be a proper - husband.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: 80 you're waiting for Richard to return from the crusades? Do not hold your breath. Marian shoots him another look.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: Clearly you know nothing of love, Sheriff. Of the sacrifices a person can make in ite name. Tornham shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I know a good deal about love ~~ but what I love is justice. And I am prepared to make sacrifices in its name. Marian keeps glaring up at the Sheriff --

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: I have to go. (standing up) My patients need me.

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: You say he was “unjustly” outlawed?

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: He came to the defense of a miller who had killed one of the king's deer to feed his starving family. The miller was executed and Robin sentenced to be blinded for having defended him. He fled to the forest.

dialogues.speaker: TORNEHAM
dialogues.text: And began taking bis revenge upon the Nobles who ruined his privileged life by hunting them -~ the way the miller hunted the king's deer. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TORNHAM (cont'd) {a beat) Do you still see him? Marian doesn’t reply ~- instead she turns and heads back inside the hospital. Tornham just watches her go... and sighs. She is guite beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (to himself) I could just torture it out of you, you know. Cur TOs EAT. NOTTINGHAM - MAIN GATES — DAY The Guardsmen share a FLASK and watch over the hustle and bustle of the city -- until suddenly SEVERAL HORSES come charging towards the gates...

dialogues.speaker: GUARDSMAN
dialogues.text: What the hell...? Each horse has a RIDER -- but they are all NAKED, tied ac their horses’ backs! cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The naked Riders -- Tornham’s RETAINERS & ESCORTS, all of them bruised, battered and bloadied -~ are being untied f their horses by the Guards. Tornham and Squire Thomas arrive, followed by Gisborne an couple of his Knights ~--

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: RETAINER
dialogues.text: Outlaws, sir. ALL dressed in green, blended right inte the trees they did.

dialogues.speaker: RETAINER
dialogues.text: Ambushed us, stole the wagon, all your baggage -- stole everything.

dialogues.speaker: ESCORT
dialogues.text: (nursing a BLOODY WRIST) Weren‘t sneaky about it either. Leader was a real braggart. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESCORT (cont'd) Called himself “Hood” and said he didn't care who knows it. Gisborne smiles at Tornham -- “I told you so.” Tornham takes a deep breath. Turns to Squire Thomas, tens

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: My chess set. Tell me you took it with us. The old man shrugs apoloegetically --

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: I, um... J thought it was less likely to be lost or damaged if I left it in the wagon, sir. Tornham nods. Tries to get control of his anger.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (to his men) Anyone besides Jack injured? The Retainers exchange looks, shake their heads. Tornham turns to Gisborne ~~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: These men will be joining the castle garrison. See to it that they are cleaned up, get them hot food, any medical attention they need and show them to their quarters.

dialogues.speaker: . SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: (chiming in) We'll get them some clothes as well. Tornham shoots bis old squire a look, then marches back inside, visibly upset... cur TOs

dialogues.speaker: S
dialogues.text: A COMMOTION has begun. People are GATHERING and a palpabl EXCITEMENT is in the air and now we see what it’s about:  31. A vast PROCESSION is approaching the outskirts of the cit it‘s a ROYAL HOUSEHOLD travelling on HORSEBACK and in WAG everything from COOKS and BUTLERS to PRIESTS and COUNSELO carrying their packed-up kitchens, beds, desks and docume with them, all watched over by a atrong force of FOREIGN MERCENARY KNIGHTS. Up at the very front a HERALD announce

dialogues.speaker: MAKE WAY FOR HIS GRACE PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: PRINCE JOHN wears a modest crown on his head and a well- trimmed beard on his youthful 25 year-old face. He is one the most powerful men in Bngland and not at all bad looki but bitterness and insecurity fill most of the space wher his confidence should be. He flashes insincere smiles at gathering SUBJECTS as they WAVE and CHEER and CALI, HIM B NAME -- though when the Subject in question is an attract woman or girl his smile grows more heartfelt. Riding beside John is ELEANOR OF AQUITAINE ~- who has remained THE QUEEN OF ENGLAND, despite the fact that her Richard ~- the absent King -- is married to a queen of hi own. At age 72 she is still strikingly attractive and an excellent horsewoman. Prince John grins at hig mother:

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: Do you hear them? Can anyone dispute that I am loved by my people?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Love is a fine thing, my son -~ but swords are more dependable, castles more defensible and gold more easily transferable.

dialogues.speaker: ES
dialogues.text: & sun-dappled GLADE deep in the greenwood. The same power STAG present at the double-murder scene cautiously emerge from behind a wall of trees and bushes. He cocks his head with their huge antlers and listens for a moment -~ then RACES OFF AT TOP SPEEDO deeper into the forest... The PIERCING NOTE OF A HORN echoes amongst the trees ~~ ~~ then a PACK OF BLOODHOUNDS comes CHARGING after the St

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and a half-dozen HORSEMEN COME CRASHING out of the tre behind the dogs. Prince John is in the lead and with him the most powerful NOBLE MEN and WOMEN from his household the Nottingham area ~~ including Guy of Gisborne, Sheriff Tornham, Queen Eleanor and Lady Marian, escorted by a str force of ROYAL GUARDS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stag pauses where several THICK OAKS have been uproot by storms and formed a FOREST CAVE, complete with a narro shadowy entrance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince John leads the hunt deeper into the woods at full

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PACK OF HOUNDS reach the FALLEN OAK CAVE and freeze i their tracks, SNIFFING around the shadowy entrance -- Prince John and his hunting party gallop up and rein in t horses. A moment later the DOG KEEPERS arrive on foot --

dialogues.speaker: DOG KEEPER
dialogues.text: The hounds have him, Your Grace!

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: (smiling to his fellow hunters) Question is ~- which of we noble hounds will have his blood? Prince John draws a pair of DANISH THROWING AXES from his saddle, DISMOUNTS and carefully approaches the Oak Cave. other Noblemen all draw axes, spears or bows and dismount well ~~

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Take care, Your Grace, A cornered beast is the most dangerous of all.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCES JOHN
dialogues.text: True, Six Guy. But no beast has escaped my axes yet... SUDDENLY SOMETHING CRASHES OUT OF THE OAK CAVE -- not the Stag, but a WILD BOAR who uses the cave as his lair! The Boar CHARGES STRAIGHT AT PRINCE JOHN! The Prince freezes in fear --  33. -- but Tornham RUSHES OVER and IMPALES the beast on his

dialogues.speaker: SPEAR
dialogues.text: The huge Boar struggles ferociously, YANKING the spear OU TORNHAM'S GRASP and GOERS FOR JOHN AGAIN ~~ -- but just before he is upon the Prince another member o the Hunting Party LAUNCHES AN ARROW STRAIGHT BETWEEN THE BOAR’S EYES, KILLING HIM INSTANTLY! The archer is Lady Marian. Everyone breathes a huge sigh of relief as the boar colla in a heap. Prince John steadies his nerves -- then forces a thankful grin to Marian and Tornham.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: Lady -~ six. My deepest thanks. Queen Eleaner and the other Lady Hunters ride up. The Que quickly takes in the scene ~~

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Are you all right, John? John struggles to keep his anger in check --

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: Never better, thank you, mother. Prince John SUDDENLY DRAWS HIS SWORD AND HACKS AWAY at th dead boar, aplattering himself with blood. He wipes his f sheathes his sword and RAISES UP TBE BOAR'S DECAPTTATED H

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: A fine trophy indeed -- (to Marian) ~~ for you, milady.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: That's... very kind of you, Your Grace ~~ but T couldn't, veally. The walle of my father’s home are already crowded with too many of its like.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: t{helding the head out to Tornham) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRINCE JOHN (cont'd) Then you, Sir Robert -- a freshly- butchered beast for a freshly— appointed sheriff. What could be more fitting? Tornham stands there uncomfortably for a long moment, all eyes on him ~~ then decides to “go with the flow of blood to speak, takes the head from Prince John's bloody hands, smiles humbly and bows -~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I can't think of a thing, Your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: Good. (glancing at all the dead Boars) Now, as my mother knows well, I always choose venison over pork ~- so the hunt must go on! Tornham HANDS THE SEVERED BOAR'S HEAD OVER to one of the Royal Guards, then mounts up...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. SHERWOOD FOREST ~ ROYAL HUNTING LODGE -— DAY Prince John's MERCENARIES stand guard outside a RUSTIC CA watching over the HUNTING PARTY as its honored members re and recover from their strenuous activity. The honored guests are WAITED ON by SERVANTS who busy themselves ROAS and SERVING choice cuts of freshly killed game. A tall, brawny KING'S FORESTER clad in leather and animal hides IMPALES the severed BOAR’S HEAD atop a SHARPENED ST A moment. later Prince John emerges from the Lodge, havin exchanged his blood-drenched clothes for fresh and even m stylish garments. John approaches the Forester, wha bows his head and steps away, leaving Jobn to stare into the DEAD EYBS of the sev Boar's Head. John spota Tornham in the crowd and gestures him. Tornham approaches...

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: Walk with me, Sheriff. Tornham falls in beside the Prince as he makes his way through the HUNTING CAMP, emiling and waving to his GUEST he goes...  35.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: Tell me, Sir Robert -- why do you think you are the Sheriff of Nottingham?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (slightly confused) Because... your brother the King chose me.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: Wrong. {a beat) God stays in heaven and the Devil in hell and a king of England cannot rule his kingdom from Cyprus ~~ ox Jerusalem. You are Sheriff because I choose to let you be. You have some reputation as an able man of both action and intellect. I have heard you share my own interest in administration and law, unlike my brother -- whose interests, as you must know, are limited to war and poetry. Make yourself useful to me today, while I rule England in his absence, and there is no limit to what may be in store for you tomorrow. John gives Tornham an affectionate slap on the back, then spots an ATTRACTIVE NOBLEWOMAN amongst the guests, turns Tornham and makes a bee~line to embrace her... Tornham GLANCES AROUND, spote Marian speaking with the Ki Forester by the impaled Boar's Bead, ‘Tornham walks over

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Remarkable shot. Did Locksley teach you? The King’s Forester glares at Tornham ~-

dialogues.speaker: KING'S FORESTER
dialogues.text: i taught her, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: (introducing the Forester) My uncle, Hugh Fitzwater -- the King’s Forester.  36.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (impressed) Lucky for His Grace, Prince John.

dialogues.speaker: KING'S FORESTER
dialogues.text: (with concern, RE: the gathered Royal panoply) T hope you don’t plan on this party lasting past sunset.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I'm well aware of the security issues involved. We shall be gone long before then.

dialogues.speaker: KING'S FORESTER
dialogues.text: Good. HUGH gives Tornham a curt nod of deference and marches of

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: Archery’s not the only thing I'm good at, Sheriff... Tornham watches Marian stride over to where he horse is tethered, unfasten its reins and MOUNT UP —~

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m also quite the horsewoman. With thet, Marian spurs her horge and GALLOPS AWAY from t Hunting Party, past the Royal Escorts and off into the FOREST. Tornham frantically MOUNTS UP on his own HORSE and GALLOP

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: vides DEEPER AND DEEPER INTO THE WOODS all alone ~~ until Tornham catches up with her...

dialogues.speaker: TORNBAM
dialogues.text: Lady Marian! T don't know what you're doing but that’s enough of it! We must. turn round and return te the Hunting Lodge!

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: Must we? I know Sherwood as well as I know my father’s house!  37. SUDDENLY THE STAG LEAPS OUT FROM BEHIND SOME BUSHES, then takes off at a dead run!

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: There! Marian CHARGES her horse after the buck! Tornham races his horse after her, trying to catch up —— she's got a head start and she knows these woods better t he does, ZIGGING and ZAGGING her way through the trees, bearing dewn on the deer ~~ Tornham starts to fall behind, only CATCHING GLIMPSES of Marian through the thick foliage as she gallops after the deer ~~ He CRASHES through a tangle of HEAVY BRANCHES and suddenl reigns his horse to a stop -- Marian is gone.

dialogues.speaker: TORNEHAM
dialogues.text: Pam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tornham lets out a sigh of frustration, RIDES DEEPER INTO wooDs, searching for any sign of Marian or the Hunting Party. oe Still nothing. And now he's coming to the realization that he’s lost. He reins in his horse, curses under his breath -- then cu his hands to his lips and CALLS OUT:

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: Wo reply. Torphem raises his HUNTING MORM to his lips to blow a sig ~~ but the born is sudden)y SHOT OUT OF HTS HAND BY AN AR Tornham spins his horse around in shock and surprise and for his sword -- ~~ but ANOTHER ARROW CLEAVES THE SADDLE-STRAP OFF THRE BE KIS HORSE, sending him SLIDING BARD TO THE GROUND, losing grip on his sword as his horse NEIGHS in fright and GALLO into the woods!  38. Stunned, Tornham pulls himself to his feet, searches the ground for his sword -~ then freezes. Hears something RUSTLING amongst the trees... SUDDENLY a pack of HOODED and MASKED MEN in GREEN and BRO come LEAPING DOWN AT TORNHAM FROM OUT OF THE TREES ABOVE! Tornham starts RUNNING through the woods, the HOODED MEN

dialogues.speaker: CHASING AFTER HIM
dialogues.text: Tornham SPRINTS as fast as he can, suddenly skids to a ha as ANOTHER PACK OF HOODED MEN EMERGE FROM AMIDST THE TREE FRONT OF HIM, cutting off his escape! He SPINS and TEARS OFF in yet another direction, the two bands of Hooded Men JOINING up and CHASING AFTER him! Tornham suddenly FALLS THROUGH THE GROUND into a DEADFALL PIT -~ a DEEP HIDDEN HOLE covered over with broken branch and gras¢! The pack of Hooded Men ~- their faces CAMOUFLAGED with dr mud and lime -- converge on the deadfall, gripping swords axes -- ~~ SUDDENLY TORNHAM’S HAND STABS UP OUT of the pit, grabs of the Hooded Men by the ankle and YANKS him into the hol Tornham is CLINGING PRECARIOUSLY to the edge of the pit w one hand and using the other to GRAB another startled Hoo Man and DRAG him down into the pit also! Tornham PULLS HIMSELF out of the hole and KNOCKS A THIRD HOODED MAN int the pit before his remaining enemies CONVERGE on him —~ fornham is outnumbered but fights like a professional soldier, DONGING their sword thrusts, looking for his ope and taking it, using his hands as BRUTAL WEAPONS, breakin NOSES, bruising THROATS, snapping WRISTS and ARMS with violent efficiency! Tornhan suddenly SEES something -- it’s hie horse, lese t 50 yards away, standing there, confused. Tornham raises two fingere to his lips, WHISTLES ~~ The HORSE starts to GALLOP towards Tormham —~ Tornham POUNDS ACROSS THE FOREST FLOOR, RUNNING AS FAST A CAN towards his approaching horse, glancing back over his shoulder to see he ig again being CHASED BY THE REMAINING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tornham reaches his horse, LEAPS onto itas bare back, gra the reins, spins the animal around and RIDES AWAY from th Hooded Men, GALLOPING OFF to safety --- ~~ just as AN ARROW SUDDENLY WHISTLES THROUGH THE AIR AND

dialogues.speaker: BARELY MISSES HIM
dialogues.text: But the arrow wasn’t aimed at him and goes on to HIT ITS TARGET by SLICING THROUGH A ROPE attached to some sort of RIGGING up in the branches —~ -- which RELEASES a HUGE LOG hidden in the trees above an SENDS IT SWINGING RIGHT FOR TORNHAM —- -- who is KNOCKED RIGHT OFF HIS HORSE by the SWINGING LoG TRAP! He FLIES BACKWARDS THROUGH THE ATR and LANDS HARD o the ground. fornham -- barely conscious, the wind knocked out of him stares up at the TREES and SPIES a Hooded Man perched on branch with a STRONG-BOW in his hands. The Hocded Man looks down at the bruised and battered Tornham, then THROWS BACK HIS HOOD ~~ revealing a strikin handsome FACE, lips spread in a ROGUISH SMILE:

dialogues.speaker: HOODED MAN
dialogues.text: Welcome to Sherwood. Just before losing consciousness Tornham realizes that th good-looking and gleeful fellow can only be one man -~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (barely audible} Locksley... Tornham’s eyes roll up inte his head and everything GoRS BLACK. HOLD FOR A MOMENT. Then the WHISTLING SOUND which we now recognize as an ARR piercing the air ~~ SMASH CUT TOs

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: as his eyes SNAP OPEN --— just in time to SRE the ARROW c straight at him -- then BARELY MISSING HIM, thudding into tree behind his head just inches from his face.  40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tornham has awoken to find himself BOUND TO A MASSIVE TRE TRUNK, arms stretched out at the shoulders, tied there li Christ on the Cross, his entire body surrounded by the JUTTING SHAFTS AND FEATHERED VANES OF DOZENS OF ARROWS. THIRTY YARDS AWAY the now un-hooded Hooded Men -~ who are course the MERRY MEN -- are DRINKING, EATING, LAUGHING, PLAYING DICE... and using Tornham for target practice wit their bows and arrows.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD, (HOODED MAN)
dialogues.text: Good of you to join us, Sheriff. Tornham watches tensely as ROBIN HOOD notches an arrow on string, drawa the bow, aims and fires -~- sending it SOAR

dialogues.speaker: STRAIGHT AT HIM
dialogues.text: The arrow hits dead center on its target, eliciting UPROARIOUS LAUGHTER from the ranks of Merry Men: it has lodged in a NARROW STRIP OF BARK visible between Tornham’ legs, just below his crotch.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: {NOTCHING another arrow) Lucky it's not me up there -~- my cock would've just lost near half its length! The laughter DOUBLES --

dialogues.speaker: MERRY MAN
dialogues.text: That‘’s not what I heard, Robin!

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: From your sister, eh? The laughter TRIPLES as Robin Hood shoots his arrow, this time sending it thudding into the tree just above Torpham head. Tornham struggles against bis bonds but it’s ne use -~ he can’t budge an inch.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Relax, Sheriff. From the dungeon of Sherwood there is no escape. Bloodied, bruised and humiliated, Tornham narrows his eye and speaks, slowly, deliberately:  Al.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I.oeo want... my... chess-set, A confused look between Robin and his men.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Your what? Tornham grits his teeth, tenges

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: My chess-set. I want my chess-set back. Robin Hood raises an eyebrow in disbelief —-

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Is that all you can think of at a time like this?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I_want my bloody chess-set back! Silence ~- until beth Robin and the Merry Men ERUPT in LAUGHTER. Robin Hood carefully notches ANOTHER ARROW -~

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: You must be quite the player. ~~ then FIRES, SPLITTING THE HAIRS ATOP TORNHAM’S HEAD.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: You, gix, are a brigand, thief and murderer ~~ and I swear before God almighty and your ragged mob that you shall be brought to justice!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MORE LAUGHTER rolls from the Merry ranks. Robin Hood marc up to Tornham and proceeds to retrieve his arrows From th tree around the bound SherLff...

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: {to his men) He's got nerve, does he not? (to Tornbam) T’LL tell you about “justice, * Sheriff: I was outlawed without CAUSE» (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOOD (cont'd) All the land T held as a loyal tenant of the King, the land my father held and his father before him -- all was forfeit and taken by Prince John, and every possession I owned sold off and every half-penny ef profit pocketed by that tyrannical bastard.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: If you were unjustly outlawed you should have lodged a plea in court.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: With Guy of Gisborne overseeing the inquest? I'd sooner be tried in hell by a jury of the damned with Lucifer himself as Judge. Tornham shakes his head:

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: You were a noble. If you doubted the fairness of the court here in Nottingham you could have taken your plea all the way to the King’s Court of Justice at Westminster in London. For the first time since we met him a serious look fills Robin Hood's face:

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: The courts be damned. They administer Norman justice for those of pure Norman blood. When a lowly Saxon such as myself -- {GESTURING to his Men} o~- or one of my men is involved, justice is banished from court.

dialogues.speaker: MERRY MEN, (VARTOUS)
dialogues.text: Aye! -- That's no joke and right! --
Tornham looks at the crowd of green and brown-clad woodsm then back at their leader...

dialogues.speaker: TORNBAM
dialogues.text: So you wrap your murder and robbery in a hloocd-soaked flag of rebellion? Tell me -- Earl of Locksley ~~ do you know anyone of “pure” Norman blood? I don't. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TORNHAM (cont'd) Norman and Saxon have been enthusiastically inter-breeding their bleed for more than a century. You’re stuck in the past, "Robin Hood” ~- we're all English now. Robin Hood glares at the Sheriff -~ then DRAWS HIS SWORD POINTS IT at Tornham’s THROAT -~

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Lots of Norman bleod in those veins of yours -- eh, Sheriff? Tornham’s eyes blaze with defiance:

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Murder a helpless prisoner. I would expect no less from the likes of you. Robin Hood flashes a rather charming grin -~

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Sorry to disappoint you then... -- and uses his sword to CUT THE ROPES binding Tornham to tree.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t bring you here to kill you —- or even for the high-price in gold you would earn in ransom. I brought you here to tell you that though I am indeed guilty of many things, I’m not the murderer you seek. (shrugging) Now I’ve got to cover your face so you can’t come back to kill me. Stick te your castle of stone and leave us to ours of bark and branch. Tornham cubs his raw weiste, contemplates attacking Robin ight then and there -~ but there are far too many of the outlaw's men surrounding all around. Instead ha locks eye with Hoods

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: The lew doesn’t end at the edge of the forest. Robin Hood’s perpetual smile disappears, replaced with a intensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A STEADY DRIZZLE starts raining down on the forest... Robin Hood slips on his HOOD:

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Yours does. Robin Hood nods to a HULKING WOODSMAN »- the biggest of a rather big bunch. He steps up, COVERS Tornham's eyes with BLINDFOLD, takes him by the shoulders and starts leading away -~ but Tornham stops short ~-

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Robin Hood turns, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: My name is Robin Hood.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Whatever you call yourself... {with an edge) Lady Marian Fitgwater is not of pure Saxon blood -- is she? Robin smoulders. He calls to the Hulking Woodsman: Koop Little Jobn, take him back where he belongs -- and don't hurt him on the way ~- unless he mentions her again.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE JOHN
dialogues.text: Done, Roh. The pattering DRIZZLE continues as Little John takes Torn in his hands and LEADS BIM OFF into the woods, Robin Hood watching them go... CUT TOs

dialogues.speaker: ERT. MANORAOUSE
dialogues.text: The vain is now POURING on the grounds where the young co was murdered -~ also the home of Lady Marian Fitzwater. Tornham emerges from the edge of the woods ~~ bruised, cu soaked and looking like hell.  The blindfold hangs around his neck and he’s in the UNTYING his bound hands with his teeth. He marches ENTRANCE to the house, face grim, nostrils flaring, the door and waits... After a few moments a thin SLOT on the heavy wooded SLID OPEN -- revealing the aging BYES of an OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN, (FROM BEHIND THE DOOR)
dialogues.text: Who are you -- and what in God's name do you want at this hour?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I’m Robert Tornham, the Sheriff of Nottingham. My apologies for the lateness of the hour, Lord Fitegwater, but I must insist on seeing your daughter ~~ at once.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN, (FROM BEHIND THE DOOR)
dialogues.text: ¥You want to see my daughter...? midst of up to the POUNDS on door is We hear the sound of several bolts being THROWN, the door opens a CRACK -~ then swings WIDE OPEN and the Old Man us Tornham with a BEAMING SMILE:

dialogues.speaker: LORD FITZWATER, (OLD MAN)
dialogues.text: Well, by all means, good sir, a strapping noble fellow such as yourself comes to see my Marian at this hour, it must be a matter of some importance! A proposal of marriage perhaps? Tornham smiles back at the Old Man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marian sits in her bed, wearing a 12th Century nightgown. She has an open MANUSCRIPT in her lap and is JOTTING NOTE the MARGINS with a QUILL PEN as she READS... Tornhan SUDDENLY THROWS OPEN the door, marches in. quickly wraps a BLANKET over her nightgown -~

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: Sheriff? What are you doing here? We feared you were logt or killed or m=

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: Betrayed. Marien  46.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: T have no idea what you're ~~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (in her face) You led me into Robin Hood‘s hands like a lamb to the slaughter. Marian is speechless for a moment. Then regains her composure and speaks curtly ~~

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: That‘s ridiculous. Is it my fault that you couldn't keep up? I am just a woman, after all. (a beat) Tell me, did you learn anything during your time in the forest?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: That Robin of Locksley is not the killer you seek.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Really? He nearly killed me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: “Nearly,” Sheriff? Se you made a heroic escape from his evil clutches? Tornham hesitates fox an uncomfertable moment, then answe ‘TORNHAM Wot exactly.

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: iosee, YT take it that means if he wanted you dead... you would be?

dialogues.speaker: TORMTAM
dialogues.text: (tight } Ne will Live to regret passing up the chance to kill me today. It won't come again. Tornkham notices for the first time that Marian’s hair is loose around her shoulders... then eyes the MANUSCRIPT in hands:  Al.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: What's that you're reading? Marian narrows her eyes at Tornham, caught a bit off-guar his interest.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: A new telling of "Tristan and Isolde” by a Frenchman named Beroul.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Beroul‘’s only original contribution to the ancient tale is to have Tristan kill Godwin with an arrow through the eye -- the way your fiancee would have done it. Marian glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: I haven’t gotten that far in the story.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Sorry. Didn’t mean to ruin the ending. Marian shrugs back at. hime

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: I believe the love triangle between Six Tristan, Lady Isolde and her husband the King is a metaphor for our own spiritual struggle -~ the choice between duty... and pasaion. Tornham thinks on that one for a moment, then notices the writing in the marging and steps closer to Marian ~-

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: {self-consciously} My notes. Alternate Lines, commentaries, critiques of the text. I myself write on occasion. Poetry.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (impregsed) King Richard writes poetry in his first language -- Provencal.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: Is it any good? Tornham carefully weighs his answer...

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: Passable at best. But if you tell anyone I said it’s less than genius I'll probably be executed for treason. Marian can’t help but smile:

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: So... it seems I hold your life in my hands, Sheriff. Tornham looks from Marian's words to her eyes. She looks back. The silence between them grows intense -- then:

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: My name is Robert. {a beat) Do you ever let anyone read your poetry?

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: No. But you must remember, most of the people around here can’t read.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: What about Locksley? Can he read?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: He reads my heart. Tornham nods, thinks this over.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: You told me I'd be dead if he wanted me go. I tell you he doesn’t know what he wants -- other than to serve his own pride. They keep staring at each other ~- ~~ but the moment is broken by the LOUD SOUNDS OF BELLS

dialogues.speaker: VOICKS, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: ALARUM! ADLARUM! ‘ALARUM! Tornham goes to the window -- spots a GROWING CROWD in th near distance, carrying by TORCHES and STORM-LANTERNS ~~ cur Tos EXT. GREAT NORTH ROAD — NIGHT Tornham marches down the road towards the RIVER TRENT and relatively new STONE BRIDGE which crosses it. The CROWD i gathered at the foot of the bridge, still RINGING THEIR HANDHELD BELLS and CALLING OUT THEIR ALARMS ~~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tornham reaches the CROWD ~~ it’s made up of half-a-dozen SERFS and a few TOWNSPEOPLE...

dialogues.speaker: CEASE YOUR ALARM
dialogues.text: The Crowd turns its attention to Tornham ~~ just as SQUIR THOMAS and GISBORNE arrive with a force of SERGEANTS from Castle Garrison, all on HORSEBACK.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: Six Robert?! (DISMOUNTING and racing over to GRAB him by the shoulders) You're all right!!! Tornham nods:

dialogues.speaker: TORNDAM
dialogues.text: Alive at least,

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: Thank god fer that} (WHISPERING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feared if you were dene for they might promote me to Sheriff. Gisborne dismounte and walks up to Tornham --

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Sheriff! This is a happy surprise. Were you lost ~- injured ~~ captured?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Sir Guy. (to the Crowd) Who raised this Hue and Cry? A young SERF hesitantly LIFTS HIS HAND...

dialogues.speaker: SER
dialogues.text: Begging your pardon, sir, but it was me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Were you victim of a crime?

dialogues.speaker: SERF
dialogues.text: No, sir. It was my lord and master, sir Walter LeGriff. (shaking) It's horrible, sir...

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: SERF
dialogues.text: Hugo, six.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Well, Hugo -- it’s now your duty to show us what you found and tell us what you know. cur TOs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yornham, Gisborne, Squire Thomas and the CROWD march thro the rain, STORM-LANTERNS held in their hands, all FOLLOWI Hugo to the RIVERBANK...

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Master Walter went fishing ag usual ~~ but he's always back before nightfall, When he dida't return T went looking and that's when I found... Hugo trails off, hig hands now shaking uncontrollably... They have reached the EDGE of the riverbank -— and the BO  Si. Tornham takes a STORM-LANTERN from the CROWD and holds it over the corpse of a well-dressed MAN in his 40's, sprawl on his back, eyes wide open, face contorted in agony, blo everywhere -- an ARROW jutting out of his throat.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: {to Squire Thomas) Still fresh. {to Huge) When did you last see him alive?

dialogues.speaker: SERF
dialogues.text: After the mid-day meal but before the church-belle sound for Vespers. Tornham hands the storm-lantern to Squire Thomas, takes a from his pocket and carefully proceeds to PULL the arrow of the man’s neck. Gisborne eyes the bloody arrow:

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: “LeGriff” -- a proud Norman name. Tornham leoks down from the arrow to the dead man’s face then scoops a few traces of BEESWAX off the man’s lifeles cheeks, shows it to Squire Thomas:

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: The bees have been busy. Squire Thomas WHISPERS to Tornham:

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: At least you got here before they could sell the arrow. Tornham WRAPS the arrow in the rag, hands it to Thomas, t back the stoxm-lantern, looks over the body again, then begins INSPECTING the riverbank, the lantern ILLUMINATING wet, shadowy area ~~

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: Damn that Robin Hood. Damn him to hell. Torpham SEES a NET and FISHING POLE lying on the MUDDY GR a few yards away from the body. He casts his light over t trees nearby -~ revealing a large ARTERIAL SPRAY—TRAIL oF BLOOD covering the LEAVES.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: He was hit here ~~ the throat wound sprayed his life all over the green ~- then he stumbled towards the water... Tornham WARROWS HIS EYES at the GROUND around their feet messy and covered with the SCATTERED FOOTPRINTS of the CR He then lowers the lantern to the SHOES of the vietim -~ mud. Tornham is quiet for a long moment, considering. ‘Then --

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: You’re sure it was before Vespers? HUGO. Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TORNAHM
dialogues.text: But it didn't start raining till just. before sundown... Tornham stands, turns to one of the SERGEANTS -- TORNHAM (CONT ’D) Wrap the body in burlap, take it back to the castle.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: I'll see to the documents for the Murdrum fine...

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Noe

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Tim sorry?

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: No mardxum on this one.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: You're aware the law states that whatever district is home to foul play must be summarily fined?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: tt's a foolish law.  53.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: On the contrary -~- it deters people from thinking they can get away with murder.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Why punish an entire community for the act of one man? We face special circumstances in this case. After all -- as you, Sir Guy, will be first to argue ~~ everyone knows Robin Hood resides in Sherwood forest, not in the neighborhood of Trent Bridge. Gisborne fumes -- but nods his head in grudging acceptanc

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the CROWD) RETURN TO YOUR HOMES! King Richard and his government thank you for discharging your duties as honest subjects of the realm —- especially you, Hugo. You have helped us down the road to finding your lord's murderer and bringing him to justice.

dialogues.speaker: HUGO
dialogues.text: T hope so, sir. The Crowd begins to disperse... Toxrmham turns to Squire Thomas, WHISPERS:

dialogues.speaker: TORNAHM
dialogues.text: Tt wasn't Locksley, The old man looks at the Sheriff in disbelief:

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: Whet? How can you be certain?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (indicating the FEET of the corpse) Sic Walter LeGriff dragged himself fcom the trees to the edge of the riverbank but there's no mud on his shoes, He was killed after the mid~ day meal but before the bells rung for Vespers ~~ before it started to (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TORNHAM (cont'd) {a beat) es.at which time I was deep in Sherwood Forest, being held captive... by Robin Hood himself. Squire Thomas's eyes go wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barely illuminated by the MOONLIGHT trickling in through several expensive LEADED GLASS WINDOWS. Tornham sleeps in a big comfortable bed -- much nicer tha the one he had in Cyprus -- but his sleep is anything but comfortable. He tosses and turns ~~ -- then SUDDENLY SNAPS AWAKE with a vielent start, hyperventilating, trying to catch his breath. He calms himself down, realizes that it’s still night.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Christ... He slowly sits up naked in bed and CROSSES HIMSELF, obliv to the cold, his BREATH visible in the frosty air. He suddenly SENSES something and narrows his eyes... HEAR the faint sound of BREATHING from somewhere else in the d LOOMe ee Tornham holds bis own breath for a split-second ~~ ~~ then GRABS UP his SWORD and LUNGES, pointing it into t SHADOWS «

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: Come out or TLL gut you like a pig! Toxrnham’s eyes suddenly GO WIDE ~-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUEEN ELEANOR vises from where she has been sitting on a. chair in the corner and approaches Tornham.. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lowers his sword and drops to his knees, bowing before

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous) Forgive me, your highness -- I thought you were an intruder. Eleanor smiles:

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tornham quickly COVERS HIMSELF with his BLANKET .

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No need for modesty, Sheriff. I’ve had two husbands and five sons. There’s nothing on you fT haven’t seen a thousand times before. Tornham nevertheless pulls on some CLOTHES, then LIGHTS A

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: This is... most unusual, your Highness. I'm not sure what to say.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Say nothing. Use your ears instead. (a beat) On his way home from crusade, my son Richard -- our king ~~ has been captured by the Austrians. Pornham’s face fille with shock and disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Right now less than a dozen souls in all of England know -~ though it will be common knowledge soon enough. {a beat) A Kansom request is sure to arrive soon -~- and just as sure to demand the greatest sum since King David collected all the gold of Jerusalem to decorate the Temple of the Israelites. Taxes are going to go up again. Rather severely I'm afraid. And all methods, no matter how unpleasant, will be warranted for use in their collection. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUEEN ELEANOR (cont'd) The people will hate to pay -~ but they will love it when their money brings their hero back to them, covered in glory. {a beat) As for John... he will do everything in his power to keep the money you must raise from being delivered to Richard's captors. Queen Eleanor sits down on the edge of Tornham's bed.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John fears he has been swallowed up in Richard's shadow. I make a point of remaining at John’s side to encourage his confidence and teach him patience. I tell him every dog will have his day -- even the runt of the litter. (shaking her head) But with news of Richard’s capture... it will be difficult even for me to restrain him in the face of such a golden opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Why are you telling me all this? Eleanor leans uncomfortably close to Tornham.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Because in all of England, John's supporters are strongest here, in Nottingham. But you, Sir Robert, are not among them. That is why I worked so hard to convince John not to interfere with your appointment. Richard gave you thia job and Richard is the rightful ~~ and lawful, -- king. And a land where the king can be overthrown is a land where no law will be respected. so tell me, Sheriff... where does your duty lie?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: {quietly} To Richard... and his safe return.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (nodding) No matter what it may cost... in gold ~- or blood.  37.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Say it, Sheriff. Tornham hesitates for a moment. Then -~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: No matter what it may cost... in gold -- or blood. Queen Eleanor rises —-

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Now go back to bed. And have a good nights‘’s sleep. (a sly grin) I order it. -- then SNUFFS OUT the candle, plunging the room back int darkness. She opens the door, walks out and SHUTS it behi her, leaving Tornham very alone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WINTER SNOW drifts down as a ROYAL WAGON with a thin ES of KNIGHTS and SERGEANTS rides into the COURTYARD. The wa pulls to a halt and the VETERAN KNIGHT in command -.- dre in sweat and grime -- dismounts from his horse, REMOVES a IRON STRONG-BOK from the wagon and carries it into the KE limping a bit as he goes... cur TO: INT. NOTTINGHAM CASTLE » HALL OF TRE SHERIFF -— DAY The Veteran Knight marches in and sets the Box down on a wooden desk, which Tornham is sitting behind, then hands Tornham a RING of REYS ~~

dialogues.speaker: VETERAN KNIGHT
dialogues.text: We only stopped 10 times to sleep between Durstein and Dover -- and not once since landing. Torpham fills bis own silver cup with ALE from a small ca on his desk and handa it to the Knight ~~  58.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
