dialogues.text: Have a drink. You and your men can rest up here for the night. (examining the Box) What’s in it? The Knight slams the empty cup down, wipes his sleeve acr his mouth and SHRUGS matter-of-factly:

dialogues.speaker: LEAD KNIGHT
dialogues.text: Can't say I have any idea. Tornham UNLOCKS the Box and opens the lid. Stares inside furrows his brow, then reaches in and pulls out the contents... +..an old, somewhat rusty and blood-stained suit of CHATN ARMOR.

dialogues.speaker: HERALD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Look upon it, good people of Nottingham -- this humble suit of armor which graced the heroic body of our glorious King Richard when he fought like an avenging angel in Christ's name to free the kingdom of Jerusalem from the tyranny of the Saracens... BST. NOTTINGHAM - TOWN SQUARE — DAY The CITY HERALD is in the midst of addressing a CROWD of people who have gathered around a cross between a scarecr and a manneguin which hag been draped in the CHAINMATL th was just delivered to Tornham. A crudely fashioned CROWN sits atop the royal mannequin‘s head... HERALD (CONT’D) hook upon it -- for if such a grand and mighty king could don the humble armor ef a poor knight and cross land and sea to reach the burning sands of the desert and shed his royal blood for the sake of our holiest places, then cannot we ~~ his loyal subjects -~ reach into our pockets and find a few more pennies to help free bim from the cruel dungeon of Durstein Castle in Austria where he is held prisoner by betrayers and heretics?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment a few brave souls from the crowd approach royal mannequin. One of them reaches out to touch the roy armor -- but the Herald GRABS his hand:

dialogues.speaker: HERALD
dialogues.text: First you pay -- then you touch. The TOWNSMAN digs into his pocket, pulls out a PENNY COIN drops it into a COPPER POT at the Herald's feet. The Hera SLAPS him on the back and GESTURES for him to go ahead. T Townsman reaches out again and this time actually gets to his fingers along the links of King Richard‘s chainmail.. Others start lining up behind him... cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Saxon section of Nottingham City. Mostly PEASANTS and TRADESMEN milling about and watching nervously as THREE o the Sheriff's BATLIFF’s confront a poor, seot-covered COA

dialogues.speaker: BURNER
dialogues.text: But I paid my taxes last month!

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: There’s been new taxes levied -~ movable goods. A percentage on your wagon, your burnin’ huts and your wood.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFEG
dialogues.text: (chiming in) As well as an additional 20 percent of your earnings.

dialogues.speaker: BURNER
dialogues.text: (desperate) Christ, man -~ I'll have nothin’ left to feed my family!

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: You should feel honored. Your money's going to free good King Richard from the Austrians.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: (co the GATHERING CROWD) That's right -~ and anyone who doesn’t pay will be branded a traitor to England!  60. MURMURS from all around -- growing fear and anger from th erowd...

dialogues.speaker: BURNER
dialogues.text: T can’t do it -- I won't! How am I supposed to chop enough wood, make enough coal, if me and my boys are starving to death? How?

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: T£ you're so hungry, how about you gat some of your precious coal! The Bailiff GRABS the Burner and THROWS him towards an ENORMOUS COAL PIT, filled with smouldering embers ~~ BURNER’S WIFE NOil! Leave him alone, you bastards! She and her TWO SMALL CHILDREN try to help her husband, b the other two Bailif£’s hold them back and the first Bail grabs a handful of the Burner’s hair and FORCES HIS FACE

dialogues.speaker: TOWARDS THE HOT COALS -
dialogues.text: Suddenly a HAND STABS OUT and YANKS THE BAILIFF OFF HIS

dialogues.speaker: VICTIM
dialogues.text: The Bailiff SPINS in surprise and anger -- then freezes. it's the Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: What are you doing, Gamwill? whe Bailiff lowers his eyes, sullen, but defiant:

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFER
dialogues.text: He refused to pay, Sheriff,

dialogues.speaker: BURNER'S WIFE
dialogues.text: He gantt pay! Please... we're near broke as it is. Please... fornham surveys the crowd of onlookers, his Bailiffs, the Burner’s Wife and Children... Ke walke over to the Burner, roughly pulls the terrified off the ground, SHOVES his towards his small HUT, pushes inside --  61. INT. BURNERS HUT — DAY A dirt floor, hardly any furniture to speak of. Tornham follows the Burner inside, looks around, then loo back to the Burner.

dialogues.speaker: BURNER
dialogues.text: (starting to break down) Please, Sheriff. Have mercy. My wife and I go hungry some days -- don't make our babies go hungry too. I leve King Richard, but -~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Enough.

dialogues.speaker: BURNER
dialogues.text: Please, sir, I --

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I_said -- enough. Tornham turns away from the pathetic man, rubs his eyes, takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: God... damn... it. (turning back to the Burner, dark) These things I'm forced to do. I have no choice. It's the law. Do you understand that? J have no choice, Tornham reaches into a pocket, slips owt TWO SMALL GOLD C and forces them into the Burner's hand. The Burner looks up at him in shock and confusion.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (quietly) The bailiffs will be back in a month. Make sure you put something aside for them. And don’t tell anyone about thie ~~ or I’11 burn your tongue out myself. The Burner nods ~~ still stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EST. SAINT MARY’S HILL - DAY Tornham emerges from the Hut, DRAGGING the Burner by the collar behind him ~~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: He was holding out on you, Gamwill. The Burner hands the stunned Bailiff his TWO GOLD COINS - The Sheriff marches away, pushing through the crowd --~ w begins BOOING him as he goes... Suddenly Squire Thomas RIDES down the road and CALLS TO Tornhams

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: Sir Robert! Your presence is required at Nottingham Castle. Tornham glares up at Thomas ~~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Required by whom?

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: By our new monarch ~~ Prince John. Tornham’s face fills with unease... CUD Tos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tornham, Gisborne and several other important NOBLEMEN st gathered before Prince John...

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: I have it on excellent authority that my brother is as good as dead. In fact, by now, he may well be dead. Not one more English coin shall be wasted pursuing his exorbitant ransom, If he is to return to England it shall be as a ghost. The ransom money that vemaing shall be transferred to my cormtrol. (a beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRINCE JOHN (cont'd) Furthermore, in an effort to secure long-lasting peace with our neighbors the French, I have decided to marry King Phillip’s sister, Princess Alais.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: But you are married, Your Grace ~~ to Countess Isabelle.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: That union is such that it has never found favor in God’s eyes ~~ or mine. The Archbishop has assuced me that God wants it annulled. {a beat) My brother has led England to the very brink of ruin, largely due to hie unbridled ambition for conquest in France. This marriage shall end all that. It will set the stage for peace in our Continental territories and prosperity here at home. (chuckling) it’s true, she’s quite a bit older than I -- but the French maid is to sit beside my throne when I hold court, not share my bed every night. Tornham, Gisborne and the other Nobles stand the uncomfortably -- until Gisborne steps forward and BOWS to Prince John, saying:

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Godspeed, Your Grace -~ (catching himself) ~~ forgive me... Your Majesty. Prince Jobn smiles and the rest of the Nobles join in, echoing Gisborne’s acknowledgement of John as their new K Tornham ie the last te say, “Godspeed, Your Majesty” -- b say it he does.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. SHERIFF'S OFPICR — NIGHT Pornham is burning the midnight oi] -~ literally. LIGHT f several. CANDLES dances eerily around the place -- reveal the walls and floor are now covered with DIAGRAMS of MURD BODIES scrawled onte large PARCHMENTS.  64. Ternham downs a goblet of ALE, rubs his tired brow and go back to what he was doing -- CLEANING dried blood off ARR recovered from the crime scenes... The door OPENS and Squire Thomas enters --

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: You sent for me, Six? Tornham OPENS A SECRET COMPARTMENT in his work-desk, withdraws a small STRONG-BOX and hands it to Thomas -~ wh frowns at ite heavy weight.

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: Heavy. (guessing at the value of the contents) Must be close to a thousand crowns in here.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Twelve-hundred and fifty. You are to see to it that the full sum makes ite way to Sir Hubert Walter, the Archbishop of Canterbury. The old Squire shoots Tornham a look --

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: You’re forwarding our taxes to the Church?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: No, Thomas -~ I'm trying to make sure they go towards paying Richard's ransom, rather than preparing for John's reign. Sir Hubert is the only one who can be trusted,

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: iosee. And if we are caught? Toxnham shoots his old Squire a look of hie own -—

dialogues.speaker: TORNBAM
dialogues.text: Then we shall suffer. Squire Thomas considers this for a moment —

dialogues.speaker: SQUIRE THOMAS
dialogues.text: i'm happy to see you've thought this through.  65. ~~ then heads out with the Strong-box, leaving Tornham al

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small grouping of HAY BULLS-EYE TARGET BUTTS set up on edge of the woods. AN ARROW goes whistling through the air, THUDDING into th target, just missing the bulls~eye. PULL BACK TO REVEAL that the SHOOTER is Lady Marian.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: Damn. Missed it by a hair. (smiling) Your turn. Next to her is Tornham, a BOW in his hands also. He NOTCH an arrow, pulls back the bow-string -~

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Steady... smooth release... let the bow do the work... Tornham lets loose the shaft, the arrow sailing through t air -- -~ and MISSING the target butt altogether -- but only by few inches. Maclan stifles a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Dammit.

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: Well, youfre getting closer each lesson...

dialogues.speaker: 'TORNHAM
dialogues.text: It’s been months now,

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: Maybe I’m just a bad teacher. Tornham gives her a look, shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: f guess we can’t all be Robin Hood, can we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An instant tension between them.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) i’mese I'm sorry, I shouldn’t have —~

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: No, it's alright, it’s ~-

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I don’t sleep anymore. Marian looks at him, taken a little off-quard.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: Really? Why not? Tornham NOTCHES another arrow into his bow -~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: The list keeps growing.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: (quietly) The victims? I'm sorry. Tornham lets loose his arrow ~- another close MISS. Tornham lowers his bow, frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: For what? This ig all my fault. All the time I’ve been here I haven‘t made one bit of difference, My men are so busy beating every last penny out of the population, they've had no time to police the eity, conduct a proper investigation.

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: fo meant I’m sorry for you. A look between them.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Thank you. Marian turns and diga into a SATCHEL she brought to the archery range...

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: I wanted to give you something. It was given to me as a gift. It’s quite beautiful and I loved it. But then I realized... It didn't really belong to me. Maxian pulls out Tornhem's CHESS SET -~ the one that was stolen when his things were hijacked by Robin Hood’s men his arrival at Nottingham.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (stunned) Where... where did you get this? Marian averts her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (awkwardly, figuring it out) of course. {a beat) How did you know it was mine?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: There‘s no Queen. I've heard the Saracens detest women of any authority, so it must have come from the Crusades. And on the bottom of the board there are some Greek letters. I heard you were in CYPruS;, SQ...

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: (amiling) You’re very smart. Maybe you should have my job. Marian smiles back at him, picks up her bow, notches anot

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: How often do you play?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: As often as I can.

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: Do you win?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: All. the time.  68.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: 80 you're good? Marian lets loose her arrow ~~ another near BULLS-EYE.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Better than I am at archery, at least. (a beat) Locksley... does he play?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: (shrugging) He has no interest in games, books, things of that sort. He considers them idle pursuits of thoge lucky enough te be blessed with wealth and nobility at birth.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: That’s a little hypocritical, don't you think? He was a Noble himself.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: (defensively) He’s a very complicated man.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: And very handsome. Dashing. Romantic.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: Why, Sheriff, you sound like you're in leve with him.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: So romantic he gives his perpetual fiancee the lovely gift of another man’s prized possession. They glare at one another.

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: (suddenly dark) The lessons over, We'll meet again next. week... She begins packing up the hows and arrows, upset —-

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Marian, wait -- She hesitates, looks back at him.  69.

dialogues.speaker: PORNHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now I’m the one who's sorry. Please accept my apology. I didn't mean to upset you. (a beat) ZX don't think Locksley is complicated at all. I think he's very lucky. But his luck is about to run out. I'm going to catch him. Marian narrows her eyes at Tornham ~-—

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Turns out that despite being a brigand, Hood attends Mass regularly -~ across the river, at Fountains Abbey. There's a friar there named Tuck who ministers to him and hears his confession every other Sunday. This Sunday we'll be waiting. Marian tries to hide her panic.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: How did you learn all this?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (sbrugging) People talk.

dialogues.speaker: MARTAN
dialogues.text: Especially if they are being tortured.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: More often if they are being given enough food er coin to survive.

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: Blood money.

dialogues.speaker: TORNBAM
dialogues.text: Charity. Marian glares at Tornham with contempt... and a hint of sadness. She turns her back on him and walks away.  Tornham stands there at the archery range, alone.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: EXT. MANORHOUSE — NIGHT Quiet. A pale mist swirls through the thick night air. A small CANDLELIGHT suddenly glows from within the walls of house. The heavy oak doors creak and slowly OPEN... Marian steps out, the glow coming from a LANTERN held in hand. She carefully closes the door behind her and cautiously creeps out into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE BUSHES
dialogues.text: Someone watches as Lady Marian leaves the grounds of her manoz and moves into the WOODS... It‘s Tornham. He carries his own amall lantern, one gloved hand cupping 80 as not to let too much light trickle out -~- ~- but then he decides the risk of being seen is too grea and he blows out the flame, plunging himself into blackne as he stealthily FOLLOWS Marian into the shadowy treeline

dialogues.speaker: BST. SHERWOOD FOREST
dialogues.text: Shafts of pale moonlight plunge down from between the flo and fauna, Marian moves through the pitch-black woods alm effortlessly, the small glow from the lantern illuminatin her path -- a path she’s clearly taken many times before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silent, peaceful and dark, the dim embere of a DYING CAMP mixing with the moonlight to provide the only light. Marian slowly emerges from the shadowy fauna ~— ~- when she is suddenly SURROUNDED by a TRIO of HooD’S SENTRYS who drop out of the trees around her, swords at t ready --

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: Miss Marian --?  Ti.

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: (bowing his head apologetically) Pardon, Miss, the moon is at half-— size n’ no one told us you were coming.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: I need to see Robin. The two Sentry’s exchange an uncomfortable look.

dialogues.speaker: SENTRY
dialogues.text: Of course, Milady, I'll rouse him right away. cur TOs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ramshackle dwelling made of animal skins, leaves and tw Robin Hood lies fast asleep, a half-empty deerskin flask lying next to him, ale leaking out. Also next to him is a barely-clothed WENCH, attractive, b SNORING loudly. Little Jobn sticks his head inside, POKES Robin violently

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE JOHN
dialogues.text: Rob ~~ Rob, wake up! Boob Christ, John...

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE JOHN
dialogues.text: Marian’s here. Robin's sleep-encrusted eyes suddenly FOCUS and he hurrie starts shaking the snoring woman next to him ~~

dialogues.speaker: WENCH
dialogues.text: (groggy) Jaezus, Rob, haven't va’ had enough, lad? Fer fuck’s sake -~

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: You’ve got te get out of here, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin, half-clothed, pulls himself from inside the camouflaged tent, spots Marian approaching in the distanc led by one of the Sentries with a TORCH. Robin WAVES to her, begins lowering himself down a rope & vine LADDER at the front of the tree, while --

dialogues.speaker: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE TREE
dialogues.text: -- the Wench, still half-naked, climbs down a REAR ESCAPE HATCH, reaches the ground and quickly scurries off inte t woods under cover of the glowing moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin greets Marian with a HUG, stifling a yawn --

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Heavens, Marian, it's lovely to see you, but my men could have killed you, sneaking inte the woods at this time o’ night!

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Rob, but I had to warn you. The Sheriff knows about Fountain Abbey. You cannot go this Sunday, you cannot -- SUDDENLY A PIECING FEMALE SCREAM rips through the aight a The half-naked Wench comes TEARING through the woods --

dialogues.speaker: WENCH
dialogues.text: Alarum -~ ALARUM! Merry Men starts WAKING, LEAPING out of the dirt & grass beds, grabbing weapons, what the bell is happening -~- ? Marian shoote the panicked Wench a look, starts to say something to Robin, when —~ fornham steps out of the woods.

dialogues.speaker: TORNSAM
dialogues.text: (RB: the Wench) She’s a bit high-strung, that one. Tornham fine himself instantly surrounded by SWORD-POINTS drawn BOWS & ARROWS ~~  73. Robin glares at Marian in disbelief ~~

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Christ, Marian, do you realize what you've done?!! You've he Sheriff of goddamned Nottingham TO

dialogues.speaker: OUR CAMPSITE
dialogues.text: Marian just glares past Robin ta the half-clad Wench ~~

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: (tight, under her breath) Who the hell is she? Robin shute his eyes tight -~ the entire night has gone t shit in minutes,

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I assure you, I’m here alone and I ~-

dialogues.speaker: SHUT UP
dialogues.text: (taking a deep breath, then shrugging to his men) Kill him. Marian's eyes go wide ~~

dialogues.speaker: WAIT
dialogues.text: The Merry Men hesitate ~~

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: {to Robin) Shouldn‘’t you at least find out why he’s here?

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Are you mad? He's here to arrest me, to arxest us all!

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: That's not true, actually.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE JOHN
dialogues.text: (pressing his sword-point into Ternham's THROAT) He said shut it.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: i’m here because ~~  74.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: ~~ I_need your help! Little John lets out a SNARL of anger and rears back to S

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM IN THE NECK
dialogues.text: ~~ but Robin shoots out a hand and stops John in mid-thru

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: And why, pray tell, should I help you?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Because you would help yourself as well. {a beat) I believe you did not murder those people. But I'm the only one who does. Help me... and perhaps I can change all that. Robin narrows his eyes at the Sheriff, gets in his face.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: And why would you care what happens to me? Tornham glares back at Hoods

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: ZT don't. But I do care about finding the truth. A tense moment between them ~~ then Robin gestures to his and the Sheriff is released.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: EAL talk with you -- byt only after IT see to my Marian. If it’s a choice between clearing my name of murder and spending a moment witb her, I choose her. Marian shifts her eyes from the out-of-breath Wench to Ro Hood —~

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: Not tonight you don't.  -- then turns on her heel and marches off. COT TOs EXT. OUTLAW CAMP - CAMPFIRE ~— NIGHT Tornham and Robin sit around the fire, edgy and nervous M MEN STANDING GUARD nearby, shooting the Sheriff dirty loo Robin stares acrosa the fire to where MARTIAN sits in the distance, TENDING TO THE SICK AND WOUNDED in the ranks of Merry Men. Tornham unwraps something covered in oij-cloth...

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I've been collecting these since I came to Nottingham. Used a tincture of vinegar and thyme to clean off the blood... Tornham hands Robin a collection of ARROWHEADS...

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: (defensively) These aren't mine, I can tell you that.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: There’s a symbol that’s etched on each one. Can you see it...? Robin inspects a couple of the arrowheads, narrows his ey

dialogues.speaker: THE ARROWHEADS
dialogues.text: Two LETTERS crossed together an ornate “S* and a decorati ape * .

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Well, thare’s the proof, isn’t it? S.P. The killer's initials.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Yes, well, that would be too easy, wouldn't 2t? I've checked baptism records for all of Nottingham county. Those initials don’t match anyone who could be the killer ~~ a few children, a few old and infirm villagers. Motive to hate the Royals pexhaps but not the ability to murder them. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TORNHAM (cont'd) These were longbow killings. It takes strength and accuracy to kill someone that way. So, I’m stumped. And since you are the expert archer in these parts, I thought maybe --

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) You married, Sheriff? Tornham watches, confused, as Robin takes a swig of ALE.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: No. ‘Fraid not. Guess T haven't met the right woman. Why? Robin turns his gaze from the arrowheads to Marian, who continues tending to his men...

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Thought. maybe an educated man such as yourself could give ma advice, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: On the fairer sex? You seem to be doing fine where that’s concerned.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean the girl with the piercing scream? Jenny?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I believe she said her name was Matilda.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: (genuinely surprised) Really? I coulda’ swore it was Jenny. Ob, well. (quietly) it's hard you know. Living with a bunch of brigands in the woods. The women from all over Nottingham... serfs, towngtolk ~~ even some noblewomen -- I'm a hero to ‘em all. Don't get me wrong -- I love Marian more than life itself but... well... she’s a cultured beauty. Sherwood ig no place for her. {a beat) Do you think she’ll forgive me? Tornham shrugs and shoots Hood a look -~  77.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Why not? After all, you are a “hero.” Hood smiles, takes another swig of ale and CLAPS Tornham the back —-—

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Thanks for understanding, Sheriff -— men~to-man Yornham glares at Hood ~~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I was being sarcastic. Robin glares back at Tornham -~

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: I could still kill you, ya’ know? (a beat) But Marian would not approve. And that’s all I want from her really... approval. Robin finishes off his ale, tosses the empty flask across campsite, goes quiet.

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: You're drunk. And thig was a waste of my time. tornham rises to his feet and goes to RETRIEVE the arrows but Robin pulls them away.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: (suddenly, bitter) Think you’re se damn smart, don’t you “Sheriff? Tornham stops, turns back to Robin. HOOD (CONT ’D) (fingering the arrowheads) Sagitarii Pedestri.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: S. P, is Sagitarii Pedestri -~-  718. TORNHAM. (translating) “Foot Archer"?

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: (nodding) Good King Henry had the Latin scrawled on supplies for the infantry archers before his invasion of Ireland. To keep track of the pennies and the pounds ~~ arrows cost money, you know. Your bey Prince John led that one. (displaying the arrowheads ) These were made for John’s men.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Are you sure about this? Robin pins the Sheriff with his eyes, then shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Maybe. You said it yourself ~~ I’m drunk. Suddenly a SOUND pierces the night air -- GALLOPING HORSE Robin stumbles to his feet just as SIR GUY OF GISBORNE AN

dialogues.speaker: HORSEBACK,
dialogues.text: Merry Men leap for their UNSTRUNG BOWS and ARROWS, but ar CUT DOWN by the swords of the mounted soldiers ~~ Robin glares at Tornham across the fire --

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Bastard! YOU BETRAYED Us! Roblin ATTACKS Tornbam, but befere the Sherwood bandit ca xeach the startled Sheriff, TWO SOLDERS CHARGE THEIR HORS between the two men, TRAPPING ROBIN --

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: {yelling to his men) Take Hood alive -~ anyone else, feel free to kill! Robin turns his attention to evading his captors, ROLLING UNDER THETR HORSES, and clambering into a one of the TREE the campsite -~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the panicked firelight, Marian CHARGES at Tornham -~

dialogues.speaker: MARIAN
dialogues.text: I trusted youl! Tornham suddenly SEES something, grabs Marian by the wris and PULLS HER OUT OF THE WAY OF A CHARGING HORSE -- up in saddle sits Gisborne. Sir Guy nods down to the Sheriff -~-

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Many thanks, Sheriff. The plan worked beautifully.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: at plan? How did you find me?

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Your silver-haired Squire alerted me that you were planning to follow Lady Marian to Hood. Well done, Sheriff. Gisborne rides off, BARKING ORDERS to his men... Tornham looks back at Marian -~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Marian. Please ~~ you must believe me, I knew nothing of this. Marian ig about to reply when her attention is drawn to t SCREAMS of Robin being BEATEN AND DRAGGED ACROSS THE CAMP BY GISBORNE'’S SOLDIERS -~

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Maciani MARTIAN! Marian tries te race to Rebin's side but Tornham holds he back as the owtlaw is BOUND and GAGGED by the soldiers —~

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: (SLAPPING at Tornbam) Let go of me, LET GO, T HATE You, T

dialogues.speaker: HATE YOU
dialogues.text: Tornham just takes it as Marian keeps screaming. But we can see that he's breaking inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of PRINCE JOHN’S SERGEANTS serving as LOOK-OUTS a rustling themselves up from sleep, changing SHIFTS, one o them wiping sleep from his eyes. The sleepy Look-Out stumbles over to the side of a cliff overlooking the mist shrouded ocean and starts PISSING over the edge... SUDDENLY a BARRAGE OF ARROWS comes whistling out of the distant mist, IMPALING the Look-Out, killing him instantl The sleepy Look-Out topples over the side of the cliff an other Lock-Outes suddenly panic and grab for their weapon ~- but ANOTHER BARRAGE of ARROWS comes sailing out of the mist, and ANOTHER and ANOTHER -- Until all of Prince John's Leok-Outs are dead. A moment of eerie silence -- just the sounds of waves lap against the coast line. Then a large SHAPE starts to emerge from the mist... A SHIP -- and at the fore of the ship ig a carved and colorfully-painted FIGUREHEAD -- depicting a FEROCIOUS, ROARING LION... cur TOs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pale light of the early sun rains down on the city --

dialogues.speaker: HERALD, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: His Royal Highness Prince John is proud to announce the capture of the outlaw -- and Murderer -- Robin Hood!

dialogues.speaker: EST. NOTTINGHAM
dialogues.text: The CITY HERALD is bellowing the news to a growling CROWD onlookers -~  81. HERALD (CONT’D) A banquet in honor of Sir Robert Tornham, the Sheriff of Nottingham, will be held in the royal castle on the morrow's eve -- and a generous serving of mutton and mead shall be distributed to all the loyal subjects of Nottingham in honor of the occasion! Scattered CHEERS go up amongst the people... cur TOs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HUGE PARTY is going, ROYALS DANCING and making merry, EATING and DRINKING like pigs, Prince John and Guy of Gisborne chief amongst the merry-makers. Tornham is there, also drinking heavily, not in celebrati but in misery. He watches as Prince John holds up an EMPT GOBLET and Gisborne steps up and FILLS IT from a large JU WINE. os The “spectacle” course is served, LARGE PIES being laid o on the tables, carefully sliced open —-- and LIVE BLACKBI INSTANTLY FLYING OUT OF THE SLICED CRUST, flapping up and fluttering around at the top of the high ceiling... Prince John approaches the Sheriff, a large overflowing goblet. of wine in one hand, a huge leg of lamb in the ot

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: Nice work, Sheriff. How does the pest of Chief Justiciar of the realm sound?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: ioam... flattered, Your Highness.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: As weil you should be. (a beat) Say, where is that fine young Fitzwater wench? I know she was invited.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t be coy, Sheriff. I’ve seen the way you look at the woman. {a sly smile) The first time is always the best -- particularly when it's against her will. You know, once Hood is executed, your path to her bed will be free of obstruction. And there's no way old Man Fitawater would turn down a proposal from the kingdom's next Chief Justiciar, eh? Tornham looks at Prince John, a thousand things running through his head. Then ~~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Your Highness, the execution you speak of must be preceded by a trial. Trial by Jury is the only way to establish a clear and honest record. Hood is very popular here in Nottingham. But if he is proven guilty of these murders on the strength of the evidence, no one will mourn his death. If we execute him without benefit of trial we run the risk of creating a martyr for those you spoke of ~~ the ones waiting to raise the bloedy flag of rebellion against you. Prince Jehn stares at Tornham for a moment -~ then shakes his head -~

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: X see your point, Sheriff -- but trials are notoriously uncertain proceedings. I have no desire to place such a sensitive matter in the hands of a “jury.” Tornham takes a frustrated drink, thinks hard for a momen and gets an idea. Cur TOs  83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin Hood hangs there, CHAINED TO THE WALL, covered in b and bruises. He looks up at the sound of his door being UNLOCKED ~— Tornham nods to a DUNGEON GUARD, who escorts the Sheriff inside, then SHUTS the door behind him, leaving Robin and Tornham alone together.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: (nedding his head, trying to stay positive...) So T need to find a lawyer, eh? I've heard Stephen Glanvill is quite the advocate. What do you think of him?

dialogues.text: It's not going to be that kind of trial.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: (furrewing his brew) What doe you mean?  84.

dialogues.text: He is the Prince’s most loyal and able retainer.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM

dialogues.speaker: HOOD

dialogues.speaker: TORNAHM
dialogues.text: Listen, it is a miracle that I was even able to -~

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: (cutting him off) Gisborne’s one of the fiercest, most bloodthirsty swordsman in all of England, do you understand that? Tim an archer ~- 4 bowman. TI shoot arrows. (defeated) Christ. It's a death-sentence with drawn-out agony added for good measure and populac amusement. tornham is silent for a moment. Then ~~  85.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Rest as best you can. The Trial is set for the morning. I‘1l see what I can do about getting you some better food tonight. Tornham turns, knocks on the dungeon door and waits for t Guard to arrive... Boop Do me one better -~- go poison Sir Guy. Tornham turns and stares back at Robin -- until the Guard arrives, Lets the Sheriff out and shuts the door, leaving Robin Hood to his fate... cuUT TOs INT/EXT. NOTTINGHAM CASTLE -— ARMORY ~ NIGHT The storeroom for the castle's weapons, sited between the GARRISON BARRACKS and the BLACKSMITH’S SHOP. By LAMP and TORCHLIGHT, Gisborne is testing the sharpness of his SWOR and AXE blades and the balance of the weight of his MACE. Toxrnham enters, approaches sir Guy.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: (eyes still glued to his weapons ) Sheriff. What brings you away from the festivities?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: T’m here to ask a favor. Gisborne looks up from his weapons, furrows his brow —

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: And what. could that be?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Locksley. {a beat) Don’t kill him tomorrow. It’s not vequired by atatute. Put him down and let him yield. We will have been judged guilty by God but the final disposition of his sentence will fall back on the city’s court, which will allow me time to gather more evidence.  86. Gisborne stares at Tornham.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: And what need is there of any more evidence? Do you doubt his guilt? Tornham hesitates for a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: T want to prove the case beyond doubt. The man is a hero to many in this city. Better his guilt be unquestioned. Gisborne's eyes fall back on his weapons.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: TE I defeat him tomorrow it will be beyond dispute that he is guilty, and considering the nature and extent of his bloody crimes I find it difficult to believe even Prince John's enemies would hesitate to see a sentence of death carried out. Gisborne tightens his grip on the sword he has been SHARPENING. GISBORNE (CONT‘D) Besides ~~ John wants that criminal punished, Not just brought to justice -- but brought to blood. And John knows I am the man to do it. Always have been, always will. Tornham studies Gisborne, then shifts his eyes to where Gisborne’s freshly-cleaned SURCOAT sits hanging in preparation for tomorrow's combat. Instead of Gisborne’s usual family coat-of-arms, it bears a ROYAL BADGE OF OFFI THREE GOLDEN CUPS UPON A BLOOD-RED FIELD. TORNHAM (CONT’D) I saw you pouring John the ceremonial first cup of wine tonight. How did you earn the honor of being his Chief Butler?

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Exemplary service in battle ~~ during the Campaign of eighty-five. Tornham’s eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John’s Irish campaign? Gisborne smiles at the memory and nods his head ~~

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: And what a campaign it was. (a beat) I'll tell you that story some other time, Sheriff, For now... instead of riding into battle tomorrow, as would be my preference as a master of horse, I'll fight your woodsman on foot. I won't let him live... but I'll give him the ghost of a chance to take my life, instead of Losing his. (smiling again) It will make it more interesting. Tornham stares at Gisborne, trying to figure something ou Takes one last look at Gisborne‘s face lit by the flicker torchlight, turne and walks away...

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Tm afvaid the officiating shall be left te you, Thomas -~ as I shall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: be ill from too much debauchery at tonight's celebration. Be sure and relay my apologies to the Prince, Tornham sets aside the arrowheads in fruetration ~-

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM, (CONT D)
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Thomas -- why in God‘s name did you tell Gisborne where I was going? Why?  88. Squire Thomas sighs, sits down across from Tornham and sh his weary shoulders...

CITY FOLK of all ages and classes begin to arrive and fin seats, while VENDORS start loudly HAWKING bread, fruit, n and -- of course --- mead. EXT. NOTTINGHAM CASTLE — NORTH TOWER ~ DAWN Gisborne walks out of his Tower and LOCKS THE DOOR behind him. He is already dressed in his full suit of CHAINMAII ARMOR, SWORD, AXE and DAGGER at. his sides, SHIELD slung his back, GREAT HELM cradled in the crook of one arm. Waiting for him are several of his SOLDIERS, who rise to attention and stare suitably impressed at the splendidly lethal looking figure which he cute. Gisborne glances at the GROWING CROWD as it OVERFLOWS the benches, smiles to himself and marches of f to the center the courtyard, his Soldiers following in his wake... +a few moments later, Tornham steps out from behind a nearby stairwell and quickly but cautiously approaches th heavy oak DOOR at. the base of the Nexth Tower. It is loc from within.  89. Tornham casts a quick glance over his shoulder to make su he‘s not being watched, then digs into a pocket, pulle ou thin, IRON ROD, inserts it in the KEYHOLE and begins PICK THE LOCK... After several long moments of struggle, the Sheriff manag to unbolt the LOCK ~-- then slowly opens the door and cre inside... Int. NORTH TOWER - GISBORNE‘S CHAMBERS ~ DAWN The Sheriff entere the opulently furnished space -- quite contrast to his own modest dwellings -- and proceeds to l around. He searches a CABINET, a rack of ugly-looking EDGED WEAPO nothing. Searches Gisborne's BED, the pockets in GISBORNE CLOTHES -- still nothing. Tornham shivers in the COLD -~ then glances over at the FIREPLACE. « « Something is wrong. There are no ashes or wood.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (to himself) No need to warm your ass on a cold morning, Sir Guy...? Tornham inspects the fireplace. Looks up the CHIMNEY, swe his hand inside, pulls it out. Still clean. TORNHAM (CONT ’D) And no soot. Tornham pushes hia hand against the back WALL of the fireplace, moves his hand from STONE to STONE, pushing, probing ~~ suddenly one of the stones MOVES INWARD, tripp a mechaniam -—- there‘s &@ CREAKING NOISE and a section o rear wall OPENS... Revealing a HIDDEN PASSAGEWAY beyond. Tornham narrows his eyes, adjusting them to the darkness makes out a WOODEN STAIRCASE leading down into the shadow The Sheriff locks around, finds a small OTL LAMP next to Gisborne's bed, lights it with a flint and head down into darkness... CUT TOs  90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place ig packed with SPECTATORS ranging from INFANTS the ELDERLY. SERFS and PEASANTS from nearby farmlands to SHOPKEEPERS, ARTISANS, CRAFTSMEN, TRADESMEN and well-to-d MERCHANTS all share the “general admission” seats, while NOBLEMEN and NOBLEWOMEN have the “box seats", located alo the very front row on all four sides of the wooden barrie closest to the forthcoming action, blood and gore. Marian and her Father are among them, Marian locking tens and pale. TWO impressive looking SEATS have been left conspicuously empty atop a RAISED PLATFORM at one end of the front row. A signal is given and with a FLOURISH the KETTLEDRUMS go suddenly SILENT. A HERALD steps forwards

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: (WHISPERING)

dialogues.text: (WHISPERING back) I haven't seen ber for days, Your Grace. Jobn scowls -- then turns his attention back to the CROWD raising a hand and calling for silence:  91.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: Most loyal subjects of Nottingham, it gives us great pleasure to see you gathered here today at our Royal invitation, in order to paxtake in that most important practice of any civilized land. If speak of course, of the disposition... of ‘justice. cur TOs

dialogues.text: Tornham wipes sweat and blood from his brow, SEES the HUN BOWS and ARROWS, grabs up the first longbow and handful c arrows he can find -+

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. SHERWOOD FOREST — DAY GISBORNE continues to stalk his prey, arrow notched in hi bow -~  112.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: (YELLING into the woods) You know, Sheriff -~ the Irish dubbed John “The Red-Handed”... cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Bleeding badly, Gisborne’s arrows still protruding from h leg and shoulder, leaning up against a tree and NOTCHING own ARROW with a trembling hand ~~

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: «--but the truth is, he wasn't willing to get his hands red_ enough. I‘m the one who did all his killing for him. Tornham SEES Gisborne through the brush, takes aim and FI

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Looks up in surprise as Tornham’s ARROW sails at him -~ t MISSES, thudding harmlessly into a tree.

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Close, Sheriff ~~ but not close enough, Gisborne whips up his bow and notches an arrow at Lightni fast speed, SHOOTING BACK at where Tornham'’s arrow came!

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Leaps out of the way, narrowly escaping being impaled by Guy's return shot ~- then RACES back into the foliage, NOTCHING ANOTHER ARROW as he goes...

dialogues.speaker: SOTH MEN BEGIN STALKING EACH OTHER
dialogues.text: Firing ARROW after ARROW, barely missing one another, one hunting the other, both trying desperately fer a kill --

dialogues.speaker: A DUEL OF ARROWS
dialogues.text: erupts between the archers -- Gisborne the ace, trained o the battlefield... and Ternham the amateur, trained by Ro Hood's lover, Lady Marian —~  113.

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: pops up from behind a tree, gets Gisborne in his sights -

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: SEES Tornham, whips up his bow & arrow and lets fly befor fornham gan let fly —- GISBORNE’S ARROW RIPS through Tornham's BOW, SHATTERING it to pieces, SPLINTERS flying into his face, cutting into his fleshi Tornham drops the remains of the bow and flees for his li CHARGING back through the underbrush, weak from logs of blood, desperate -—~ Gisborne LAUGHS and gives chase ~- EXT. OAK CAVE — DAY It's the ENTRANCE to the FOREST CAVE formed from thick, downed OAK TREES -- where the boar was killed on the Roya Hunting Party months ago. Tornham emerges from the brush, SEBS the cave and drags himself INSIDE the cocoon of fallen oak, trying to catch breath -- Tornham stares at Gisborne's arrow protruding from bis _ shoulder -~- then tears a piece of WOOD BARK from one of fallen oaks, puts it between his teeth and bites down bar He reaches back and BREAKS OFF the feathered END of the a —— then grips the SHAFT of the arrow just above the blood arrowhead, fights back a ery of agony and PULLS, slowly a agonizingly vanking the rest of the arrow FROM HIS SHOULD Six Guys VOICE again, thie time getting closer...

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: i learned a lot about myself in Ireland, Sheriff -- and T put that knowledge to goad use for Prince John. But then we had to come home -- to a land at peace. John had no interest in going on Crusade, so I needed another outlet for my talents. Tornham reaches down to the other arrow -- the one jattin out of his leg ~~ BREAKS OFF the feathered end and slowly PULLS THAT ONE OUT as well. A SHADOW suddenly fall over the entrance to the oak cave Tornham focuses his pain-blurred vision and SEES Guy of Gisborne standing over him, bow slung over his shoulder, gword in hand. Gisborne GRINS -- the deeply-satisfied grin of a man who been waiting for a reward for some time and is finally ab to receive it:

dialogues.speaker: GISBORNE
dialogues.text: Your head will make a fine trophy, Robert Tornham. Gisborne raises his sword with two~hands, prepares to LOP

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM'S HEAD --
dialogues.text: But Tornbam suddenly grips the arrow that he pulled out o his own shouldex and STABS IT INTO GISBORNE'S LEG WITH HI

dialogues.speaker: BARE HANDS
dialogues.text: Gisborne HOWLS in agony, falls to one knee in front of Toxnbam -~ Yornham grips the other axrow -- the one that he pulled o of his own leg ~~ and STABS IT INTO GISBORNE’S CHEST! Gisborne gurgles up blood. He hesitates... still clutching his sword... still trying bring one last blow down on the Sheriff ~~ Then Gisborne collapses in a crumpled heap next to Tornha

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: EXT, STREETS OF NOTTINGHAM ~— DAY The bettie is over. The BANNER of RICHARD THE LIONHBARTED flies over the City flapping in the late afternoon breeze. Villagers and Nobles alike CHEER as King Richard rides through the town astride hig herse, waving to his people, part of a ROYAL VICTORY PARADE. And at his side, regal and relaxed as ever, cides his mot QUEEN BLEANOR. DISSOLVE TOs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty -- except for Prince John. He holds a SMALL DAGGER in his hand, examining it, lettin the blade hover over his heart, He STABS it down -- and starts to CUT -~ CUT TOs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King Richard trots his great warhorse right to the FRONT STEPS of the GREAT HALL -- then urges the stallion to pro on UP THE STONE STEPS... The KNIGHTS and MEN-AT-ARMS of his escort DISMOUNT, DRAW THEIR WEAPONS and follow him up the steps, as does his mother, Eleanor of Aquitaine, showing impressive agility a woman of her age -~ cur TOs

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: as tears start to well up in his eyes and streak down his faca ~~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The massive oak doors SWING OPEN and King Richard marches SURROUNDED by Knights and Men-At-Arms serving as bodyguar Suddenly they all freeze in their iron boots, their eyes glued to something at the far end of the Hall...

dialogues.speaker: KING RICHARD
dialogues.text: (FRENCH w/English subtitles) <«heave us -- all of you.>> The Koights and Men~At-~Arme turn and exit, only Queen El remaining. o.«

dialogues.speaker: KING RICHARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: <<Shut the doors, Mother,>> Eleancr does as her son instructs. As she does, the sound PAINFUL SOBBING carries from the far end of the Hall... Prince John lies doubled-over, head buried in his knees, dxesaed only in his underclothes, his fine ROYAL GARMENTS silk, satin and fur CUT TO SHREDS in a pile beside him.  Lie. Richard stares down at John for a moment ~-- then speaks him in FRENCH w/ENGLISH SUBTITLES:

dialogues.speaker: KING RICHARD
dialogues.text: <<Don't be afraid, little brother. You are young and have been the victim of bad advice. Your counselors shall pay for this.>> (growing impatient) <<Now get up and put some clothes On, >> John leaps to his feet, throws himself into Richard’s arm ana hugs him tight --

dialogues.speaker: PRINCE JOHN
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Richard. Forgive me... Richard stands there for a moment... then hugs him back. Eleanor watches, a contented smile gracing her lined but levely face...

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. TORNHAM’S BEDCHAMBER ~ NIGHT Pale MOONLIGHT trickles in through the shadows. A FIREPLA burns, warming the cold stone of the room. Tornham lies in bed, unconscious, his wounds BANDAGED. A FEMALE HAND in a NOBLEWOMAN’S GLOVE reaches out and tou Tornham's forehead. Tormham’s EYES flutter open. He focuses on the hand...

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: (barely avdible) Marian...? But the gloved hand belongs to Eleanor of Aguitaine.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Sorry to disappoint you. Tornham narrows his eyes at the Queen -— then slowly, painfully, pulis himself into a sitting position in the b

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Forgive me, your Highness.  lL.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: No apologies necessary, Sheriff. You have been overcome by your wounds for several days. That’s more than enough excuse for anything you might have said to offend my Royal sensibilities. Tornham notices that Eleanor is holding a DAGGER in her gloved hand -~ the one Prince John cut off his royal garm with.

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: So,.. who is our King?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Richard rules England once more. No small thanks to you. Tornham notices a few FLIES beginning to buzz around the dagger.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: And what of Gisborne?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Sic Guy is dead. The people say that the brave and unjustly accused outlaw Robin Hood took his vengeance on the murderer ~~ Sir Guy -~ putting two arrows into him... and algo wounding Prince John's tyrannical tax collecting lackey, the Sheriff of Nottingham. (a dry smile) what ig after brave Sir Robin discovered Gisborne’s hidden sanatum of horrors and helped the rightful King, Richard, regain his Castle. Ternham smiles with bitter amusement.

dialogues.speaker: TORNBAM
dialogues.text: He seems to have done it all, this Robin of Locksley.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR,
dialogues.text: Yes. He’s quite the here. {a beat) People need heroes, Sir Robert. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUEEN ELEANOR (cont'd) Men like yourself, steeped in law and arithmetic, help a kingdom to function properly but the kingdom itself would not exist without men like my Richard -- and your Robin of Locksley. They are the sort who will make men proud to be English -- the way Charlemagne and Roland made them proud to be French. Eleanor takes out the DEATH-LIST that Tornham found in Gisborne’s sanctum. She strolls over to the fireplace, tosses the Death-List into the flames and watches the parchment BURN... ‘TORNHAM (quietly) What did the victims all have in common, Your Highness? Were they all supporters of Richard? Bleanor raises an eyebrow at Tornham, clearly impressed.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gisborne was just following orders, wasn’t he? Doing Prince John’s bidding.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Do not mourn for Gisborne. The man was a beast.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Who is worgee, Your Highness? A mad dog -~ or the master who knowingly sets that dog to prey on innocent victims?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELBANOR
dialogues.text: My Little boy's actions were regrettable, yes. But he is of Royal blood --- and his mistakes, no matter how bad, must not be allowed to taint the throne. And as for who ig “innocent” -- I suggest you leave that to God, Bleanor studies the wounded Sheriff for a moment ~- then steps to his bedside and leans in close, the dagger still clutched in her hand ~~  Lig. QUEEN ELEANOR (CONT‘D) (a tight WHISPER) You know, Sir Guy didn't die in the woods, Sheriff. He was still alive when the both of you were found. He was brought back to the Royal Physicians... but they were powerless to do anything except watch him.. expire. The Sheriff stares as MORE FLIES land on the dagger ~~ a slight BLOODSTAIN visible on the blade as it catches a sl of moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: And what is my fate to be, Your Highness? Eleanor studies the Sheriff for a moment... then gently KISSES his forehead and rises.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: As you well know, the people have nothing left to tax and times are very hard -- even for the Nobility. The only way Richard will be able to raise funds sufficient for his needa will be to auction off every key government post in the kingdom -— including that of “Sheriff of Nottingham.” I’m afraid you are not wealthy enough to keep your job.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: After all this, Richard is leaving England again? The Queen shrugs -~

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: What did you expect? That he would git on his throne and reign over a kingdom at peace? Pleasa. My Richard belongs in France ~~ where troubadours sing and pasaion rules. Not here in your land of bailiffs and “legal precedent.” Tornham looks away from the Queen, stares into the fireplace...  120.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Don't worry. For your services to your King -- and your future discretion -- you shall have a post in Richard's army when he sails back to France to reconquer the lands he Lost while in prison. Bleanor finally puts away the dagger, looks down at the bandaged Tornham... and smiles benevolent.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN ELEANOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's the least we can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful, sunny morning. Tornham stands by his horse, wounds still bandaged, but clean. Robin Hood walks up to him, resplendent in NOBLE FINERY...

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Lord Locksley. Robin Hood can’t help but smile ~~

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: I must admit, I like the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: As does all of Nottingham.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: But net you, eh?

dialogues.speaker: TORNEAM
dialogues.text: (simply) You were not the Arrow Killer. Since King Richacd saw fit to pardon your many other offenses and xestore your lands and titles, it is net my place to dissent.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: But it. could be your place to remain Sheriff€ of Nottingham. There's no doubt you're the best man for the job. And during my... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOOD (cont'd) less lawful period... I managed to accumulate enough funds for you to put a hefty bid in for it. (shrugging) I would simply be repaying a debt. Tornham considers for a moment -- then shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: That's... very generous of you. But I could not purchase the post of chief officer of the law with stolen money. Robin Hood LAUGHS out loud --

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Can‘t say I didn't try. Toxnham siniles tightly:

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Tell me, Robin -- after living so long as a wild outlaw in the forest... will you be content inside the walls of your manorhouse? Robin Hood grins --

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: If it’s a manorhouse fit for a king... why not?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Why not indeed. Tornham turns, mounts his horee, turns back to Robin ~~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May you spend many happy hours in the woods, all of them hunting -~ and none of them breaking the law. Tornham staxts hie horse off, but Rebin Hood blecks his p

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: And what about you, Robert of Tornham ~~ master of law and order? Where shall you go and what shall you do?

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I’m not sure. The King has offered me a post -- but I don't know if IT want to be part of another invading army.  122.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Well... whether you are hacking your way through France with King Richard... or teaching law to spoiled students at Oxford... you will always be the Sheriff of Nottingham to me, Tornham himself can’t help but amile a little at that one He reaches out and offers his hand ~~

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: I‘ ll take that as a compliment. Robin Hood takes it in his own and the two men shake.

dialogues.speaker: HOOD
dialogues.text: Now, if you'll forgive me, I have a wedding to attend. Robin Hood turns and strides away... Tornham watches as Robin Hood REJOINS A VERY LARGE AND VE JOYFUL WEDDING PARTY decorated with GARLANDS OF FLOWERS.. Robin Hood takes his place as the GROOM. «and of course the BRIDE is Marian.

dialogues.speaker: TORNHAM
dialogues.text: Up in his saddle, taking one last look, his mind filling thoughts of what might have been.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIAN
dialogues.text: Catching Tornham'’s eye and casting a glance back at him. Their eyes ave locked together for what seems like an ete Then Marian finally TURNS AWAY, her attention going back the Wedding Party and her future husband, Robin of Locksl Robert. Tornham, the Sheriff of Nottingham, turns his hor around and starts riding away, never to return... Except in folktale, myth... and legend.
